Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 03:14AM - edited Jan 2, 2011 03:24AM by MaryMeg Oh, and for the roll call,  I'm 46, and will be starting chemo on 6 Jan. AC 4 x 3 weekly, then carboplatin/taxol also 4 x 3 weekly.  Then radiation, then tamoxifen followed by an aromatase inhibitor. No port.  Aimster,  I took my first BodyPump class last week, and I thought it would kill me.  Chemo has got to be better than that (and I am strong, but clearly not fit!) Annie, my three children are 7, 10 and 12, but the 10 year old skipped a grade and thinks she's 11. :-)  I had a free TRAM reconstruction when I had my BPM 4 years ago (and it was a beautiful job), but they took the flap out to clean things out with this cancer.  (The cancer was near the sternum and they wanted to get all the nodes so I'd have ended up looking like a bad lawnmowing job if they took a strip off each side and left the middle, so out it all came. Hmph. (My biggest worry was that they'd remember that my breast was made from tummy tissue and attempt to put it back on my tummy.  Now, THAT would have made me unhappy!) I can have a lat flap reconstruction when this is all over if necessary.  And I had my ovaries out 5 years ago (that BRCA thing again), so I went into menopause at 41, so at least that is done! And I live in New Zealand, but I'm a Canadian (from Toronto) and my husband is Australian so I'm mostly really confused about where I belong.    Mary Margaret, shutting up now. (For the moment.  Maybe.)

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 12:47AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi everyone,  Add me to those utterly freaked out by scans.  I knew lots about BRCA1 and the usual cancers that accompany it by the time I was diagnosed, and I was sure that having beaten the odds to get breast cancer, even with no breasts, I was doomed to be stage IV right off the bat.  (I wasn't. :-)  I was a total nervous wreck though for the 2 weeks between diagnosis and scan results! Right now I'm not exactly a nervous wreck, but I'm more of a nervous fender-bender.  Concentration isn't a happening thing and my children are really tense and bickering all day long.  (They're like my own personal Picture of Dorian Gray--I act normal (or so I claim--my husband would debate that) and the kids reflect my moods!)  For me, busy-work with my hands (painting a room, building a treehouse :-) while listening to podcasts or playing the piano (without the podcasts) have been what works best for me.  And lots of exercise.  But doing things that put me into the zone, where I have to concentrate on what I'm doing with my hands are great--I get to the end and realize that I've completely forgotten to worry for an hour or whatever.  Recurrence is a big worry for me, as BRCA cancers that are ER+ don't respond as well to treatment as non BRCA ones, but for now I'll focus on what's right in front of me, not what's way down the road!  36 hours to go! BAF, I really like your thought that we just have to show up. :-) The taking time off work thing is interesting.  One teacher friend was off for six months last year with chemo.  Another teacher friend missed 2-3 days per cycle, and that was it.  When my mum got OVCA she never went back to work at all, and she lived 5 years. I know that the anti-emetics are better now than then, but in the last 15 years it seems to have gone from people being on leave from the day they get the diagnosis till they're through treatment, to people trying to work through it.  I know that having something to do is important, but I'm not sure that I want my energy to be going into my responsibilities to others... Good luck to anyone starting chemo tomorrow!   Mary Margaret, who went for a run today and then a BodyBalance class and THEN treated myself to 3 hours by myself at the mall as a distraction (and got my toes done).  My husband goes back to work tomorrow, chemo starts the day after, and school doesn't go back for a month.  (It's summer vacation here!)

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 01:01AM MaryMeg wrote: With respect to soy, for those who have been advised to avoid it, do you know what the evidence is that that is based on?  I've been wondering about it since I've heard that some avoid it, but the studies I'm finding are all saying that soy reduces the incidence of breast cancer, of recurrence and of mortality.  Most of those have been among Chinese or Asian-American women though. Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 11:37PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi everyone,  Melissa, your photo is beautiful!  I hope I look half as lovely bald.  (And you started chemo 3 days before me, so it's nice to know that that is likely how much time I have left.) One of my fun treats where I live is that literally EVERYONE here knows what is going on with me.  We have a shortage of medical oncologists here in Wellington, and because I'm stage II, ER+, no nodes, I was not at the top of the waiting list.  (Don't get me wrong--I wouldn't give up free universal healthcare for anything, but there are times when being rich and privileged in a hierarchy looks more appealing. :-) Anyhow, the Wellington paper ran an article on the shortage and concluded with "Are you affected by this? If so, ring this number to speak to our reporter!"  I did, and ended up on the front page of the Wellington paper.  Three times.  (Search in Google for "cancer appointment wait New Zealand" and you'll get me.  I am not putting the link in, because I do have hopes that it will vanish in time.) (If you do find the article, notice the way the photographer camoflaged my son's lunch all over his clothes by hiding him behind me.) At the time, I was very glad I did it--they need a public face on these things or change doesn't happen, and I was pretty concerned with some aspects of the situation.  But then, in one of those "people are so utterly amazing" moments.  Someone bought a lottery ticket for me (so I could travel for treatment, bless him!), IT WON $700 AND HE POSTED IT ANONYMOUSLY TO ME!! So what could I do?  I had to contact the reporter again--I just couldn't not, after an incredible act of generosity like that, but now EVERYONE approaches me on the street.  My community has about 150,000 people in it, and I apparently know them all.  Last night, the mother of someone I knew years ago (our kids were in the same preschool for 6 months) approached me at the supermarket, blithely sure that I would remember her.  (I did, but only because she has her daughter's remarkable smile.)  I am so grateful and overwhelmed by the experience so far, and by people's kindness, but really, truly, I am an introvert and would like to not be public property.   I was happy to let people I know in real life know the full story--I HATE when some people know (which, in Lower Hutt, means that everyone knows) but no one knows who is allowed to know, so it's all discussed in whispers.  And I hate it even more when kids are involved, as keeping secrets from them is pretty well impossible.  (A friend got cancer last year, and told 2 friends but not her kids.  So every mum at school knew before her kids.  That was bad.) But there is a difference between that and every clerk in every shop I go into saying, "Have you started your treatment yet?" Maybe I should get some very odd wigs and big glasses.  I could go incognito!  (If I start wearing makeup that will provide enough camoflage. :-)  Or I could go commando and paint my head a startling colour--like bank robbers who dye their hair orange to distract people from their face. Today I am on a tiny island in Wellington harbour.  It is a nature reserve and access is controlled.  (There are 5 families staying the night tonight.) The ranger who briefed us asked how my treatment was going. Ack!!!!! (I'm sure I've met her before, but I have NO idea where.  But in Lower Hutt, everyone knows everyone, and most have lived here 10 generations.  And I have an accent (Canadian) so I stand out! Anyhow I don't mean to whine--I've receive some wonderful gifts.  But I'm ready to become private again!   MM, very very glad my hair has not chosen today to start falling out.  (Yesterday would have been fine.  Tomorrow will be fine.  Taking the ferry home 1/3 bald would not be fine!)

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 06:33PM MaryMeg wrote: Citykitty,  That is utterly amazing, that you are planning to do a half next week!  Go for it! I did a few marathons before my children were born and did two halfs--the slowest ever--while pregnant with my first, but have never been able to get my mileage up enough since then to do it again.  For my final half (at 34 weeks pregnant), the fastest walker beat me. :-)  For me the iPod is the trick too--and I have to be listening to podcasts.  If people are talking to me, I forget that it's the dreaded EXERCISE!  :-)  And like you, citykitty, I just get out of bed and go.  If I am dressed and out the door within 60 seconds of the alarm going off, by the time Iwake up and realize what a silly thing I'm doing, it's too late.  If I stop and think about it, SNOOZE! Julie, I don't know if I could do the classes under normal conditions, but my only priority now is beating this, so I'm willing to do 6am classes, knowing that I can always have a nap later on if I need to.  I've been doing a plan of targetted activities.  Today I HAD TO run, make dinner, get my daughter's uniform in to be shortened before school starts in 2 weeks and a couple of other trivial things.  Beyond that, everything else is a candidate for being dropped if I don't feel up to it. Rest trumps everything!  It has helped that my sleep has been so weird, as often as not, the days of th 6am classes were days that Mr Dexamethasone and I have been up partying until 3 am, so it's not like I was going to make it through the morning no matter WHAT time I got up!   MM, now sporting a #4 haircut, but with a lovely full bag of hair to post to NSW. :-)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 11:20AM - edited Jan 25, 2011 12:23PM by MaryMeg ProudMom, it sounds like you are trying to do way too much.  Do you have to work?  Can you take sick leave for a while?  Even a few days per chemo?  Can your husband do more? Do you have anyone who could help out?  You need to prioritize--one thing that works for me is to say to myself, "Looking back, 10 years from now, will I be glad that I pushed through and did X?"  If I realize that looking back, I'd think, "What an idiot--I should have just backed off from that for 6 months!" (I hear that a lot, oddly enough) I try to listen.  I know that it's important for us to be doing meaningful things, but not at the expense of our health (literally our lives for us) and our families. (And while I'm also trying to be there for my kids' things, "being there for my family" does not necessarily include cooking a proper meal each night.  A few months of frozen meals or takeaway isn't going to kill them.) I had always assumed that if I got cancer I'd be the sort of person who worked right through, taking off only a day here or there when things were worst.  I'm finding out that actually no, I'm not that kind of person, and I'm very happy to use my former work time (admittedly volunteer work, but they are left hanging and overworked right now, just like a business would be) in exercise, rest, researching this disease, shopping for scarves online :-), and reconnecting with the friends who are helping me get through this.  I know that not everyone has that choice and I feel lucky that I can take this route. And do feel very guilty for letting my colleagues down, but this is a short period of my life and I want to get it right. The "brave, happy face" thing is a real pain, isn't it?   I've decided that the phrase, "Oh, I have my moments..." is a really useful one to let people know that it's not all TV and ice cream, and that just because I've got my company face on doesn't mean that it isn't hard at times.  I also find that when I hear other people use it, it helps remind me that we all go through that pit at times, and that others who appear fine are also struggling.  Can you think of a way that you can vent?  Would counselling help?  Talking with a close friend?  I started a password-protected blog, purely for purposes of spilling all my worry and negativity on. (I type way faster than I write, which is why it's not a paper journal.) I don't re-read it, and I plan to delete it permanently when I'm done, but I do think it's really important to get those dark things we have to deal with out there, rather than bottling them up.  Repressed emotion is really really bad for us.  (I can share the studies if you like. :-)  Keep sharing with us in any case--we get it and won't judge! I think for me, the single biggest part of this thing is figuring out how to listen to my inner self and doing what it tells me.  I'm so used to doing the "right" thing (as defined by everyone around me) and doing my duty (Can we spot the Good Catholic Girl?  The eldest child and only daughter of an alcoholic parent?) that it is very hard for me to use my own judgement on what feels right for me to do instead of just assuming that I have to do everything.  In some ways this has been liberating for me, as I reckon that there is no other time in my life when society will expect less of me. :-) It is really really hard for me to not feel like every moment needs to be full ofTHings I Must Do, but leaving some space for the unexpected nap attacks, or just to catch my breath, feels like the right thing to do right now. I really hope you do find a way to create the space for you to heal, to rest, and to deal with this stupid disease fully, rather than feeling like you have to shove dealing with it into the spaces left over in the rest of your life.     MM, who initially planned to go away and run a national meeting the weekend I got the Dx, but eventually I worked out that if my husband was returning at top speed from Singapore (leaving conference panels unchaired in the process), then possibly it would send the wrong message about my priorities if I went away for my volunteer work, however fulfilling it normally is.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 02:22PM MaryMeg wrote: Okay, I'm baaack!  Have been very slack with all things internet, which is very unlike me.  I have 200 unread emails and I normally check my mail hourly! I remain in awe of all you superwomen who have been working fulltime.  Tammy, I'm singling you  out because you're a school principal so you have the chaos of the kids AND the management/funding rubbish and a house of young kids.  Just thinking of it makes me totter off for a little lie down.  Tottering off for a lie down remains my main activity these days.  I can so I will!  I had my last AC 3 weeks ago, and went away to a volunteer thing that weekend.  (As I've said, I'm national vice president (voluntary) for an early childhood preschcool that has about 500 centres, and we have a big national meeting twice a year (and a conference in May).  I missed the last meeting (the week of my diagnosis) and the organisation came out in an uproar, deciding that a whole new structure was needed nationally.  Not a good meeting to miss.  THIS meeting they were deciding on the structure, so I really needed to be there.  I was there in spirit only, since I spent most of the actual meeting time sleeping, but I saw everyone at mealtimes. :-)  Even though I slept most of the time, it really wiped me out.  I was shattered for about 8 days after that one (although I realize AC#4 is the hardest anyhow).  Just a zombie, sleeping as much as I could, and really struggling to do the family stuff.  (Family== get kids to school in uniform, pick them up, take them to activities, feed them.  It did not include laundry, tidying or bathrooms.)  Then I spent the whole remaining 2 weeks trying to get cauaght up, and didn't get there in the end.  (Have a huge pile of clean-unsorted laundry today and some tables in the house are piled high with Stuff. Bleah.)  It was a good lesson to me though that for me, this Taking It Easy thing is really important.  I'm shocked that 3 days away had that effect on my recovery. On the positive side (and there's heaps of positive) my kids are SO happy and settled these days.  My DD has started intermediate/middle at a new school where she (a shy but social girl, if that makes sense) knew no one and it's been a bit of a struggle, but I have so much time to spend with the kids, since I'm never out at night or away on weekends (I used to go away once a month for a weekend).  I'm so glad.  Of course the fact that my brain is in just the right place to read 75 Zac Power books in a row and find them interesting doesn't hurt at all.  (Would he please stop writing those books!!  Two more waiting for us at the library today...)  It also helps that I find folding socks intellectually challenging, and I get the same sort of cognitive thrill from deciding how to load the washing machine that I used to get from writing journal articles.  On the other hand, when I try to actually read the emails about our new structure (or worse, try to comment on them), I feel the way my kids do when I hand them Faulkner to read.  This is good, and keeps me grounded and not trying to do things that would be stupid for me to be doing.  (Cf my utter awe of you that are all still working.)  I just can not see any reason to add the anxiety and stress that would come from  trying to do that stuff--especially when I'm a volunteer.  It's not like I'll lose money or run out of sick leave.  When I no longer find unloading the dishwasher a delightful achievement, it will be time to get going again. (See, you don't need me to write often--I make up for it in volume!) Am still going to they gym although after AC4, I ws the slackest yet.  Stopped classes and went to the treadmill or elliptical and predictably, the sessions got shorter and shorter.  I am getting back on track though and am increasing again.  Am not fussed if the next 3 months aren't the fittest of my life.  This is reinforced by my decision to do a hill run on Sunday--a 5 mile loop starting at the top of a giant hill.  At the bottom of the loop, as far as possible from my car, just as I was about to run (all right, walk purposefully with the odd jog thrown in on downhills) up this gorgeous river valley (and then slog up the cliff at the end to my car), the heavens opened and I got as wet as if I were swimming up the river.  Half of our region ended up flooded, cars were washed away--and I was in a river valley with no phone coverage, no roads (so no chance of a pickup) and looking like I was entering a mud wrestling competition.  Clearly Exercise Is Evil, and I'll go back to exercising my fingers on the remote control for a while instead. Started Taxol/Carboplatin yesterday. They did the whole scary "let's worry about anaphlaxis" thing with the Taxol--premeds, having it in a bed with oxygen all ready and a nurse in the room for the first 10 minutes, starting it REALLY SLOWLY etc etc.  it was fine, of course, and the carbo was a non-event.  Everyone was really thrown by it being a taxol/carbo combination, which is really uncommon there (and this is the first they've ever done for breast cancer in Wellington).  So everyone i talked to would say, "Oh, you're starting Taxol today."  "And carboplatin."  "CARBOPLATIN?"  And then there would be a mighty rustle of paperwork and attempts to look like they knew it all along. It has been very tricky finding out what meds I should be on or what the likely reactions would be or how hard it would hit etc.  Very annoying.  Finally I stopped trying to get answers from humans and went to the Australian EVIQ website, claimed to be a Health Professional (Hey, this is my full time job now!) and downloaded the protocol for High Risk Early Stage Ovarian Cancer, and it was just what I'm getting and had all the details.   Which made me very obnoxious yesterday, as I questionned dosage, prescriptions ("It says here I should have ondansetron just in case") and protocols.  ("Which one am I getting first?" "Oh, whichever they get ready first, I imagine." "It says here that it has to be the paclitaxel (Taxol) because it can interact with the carboplatin and that will increase the risk of myelosuppression and peripheral neuropathy." "Let me see that...") My old life was as a human factors engineer, and rule 1 there was that when you were dealing with new or unfamiliar situations, or were changing significant things from the familiar situations, that's when errors creep in, and Bad Things Happen, so I was happy to be a bit bolshie.  I brought chocolate chip cookies (proper, chewy ones, not the dry awful ones that people think are normal around here), so I'm hoping the bribery won me back into their good graces.  My only reaction so far has been an really annoying full body itching, but I expected that, since about 6 years ago it started happening when I got stressed.  Perfume free laundry powder mostly stopped it, but if I was goign to have any reaction, that's the one I expected.  Am just waiting on a phone call to confirm that I can take more anti-histamines.  Fingers crossed on the bone pain.  None yet, but it's early days... So 11 more weeks of this, then rads, then Aromatase Inhibitors for 5 years and that sexy Prince William pattern baldness!  So nice to feel like there is progress.  (Maybe I can marry into the royal family if I have the right hair style?) Am very glad to keep reading the updates.  Please keep in touch, even those who are moving on.  I feel like we're family and I love to know how you all are doing, even if I am the delinquent correspondent.  (I blame distance.  It takes weeks for those electrons to travel by waka from New Zealand to the rest of the world.) Love,   Mary Meg.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2011 10:10PM MaryMeg wrote: Hello again, everyone! My children are all hyped up on jelly beans and chocolate, so hiding from them (and hanging out with you all) seems like the best way to spend Easter afternoon! So glad to hear how many of us are finished chemo! Lucky ladies!  I'm 8 down and 8 to go.  I'm 1/4 of the way through the taxol/carboplatin combination (after having my last AC 6 weeks ago).  I'm on a 3 week cycle, with TC the first week, then just Taxol for the second and third.  Repeat x4. Am finding the TC combination much much harder than AC ever was.  While I felt very "not me" with AC and felt quite yucky and tired, the TC feels like I'm being beaten up by a gang.  Actually about 12 gangs, each one with it's own specialty.  One gives me mouth sores, one makes me nauseated, one gives me a full body itching including raised welts whenever I scratch.  One has been stealing my eyelashes and eyebrows, and several have been ganging up to make me very tired.  Another has been giving me chest pains and shortness of breath, one has been refusing to let me sleep, and one has been making absolutely everything taste like platinum, which is a beautiful metal when handed to me in the form of jewellerly, but is not so endearing when sprayed all over my taste buds.  Then again there is the crew who are after my fingernails (but they don't want my beautifully painted toenails--go figure?)  The last gang is stealing my red blood cells, but I'm going to thwart them with a transfusion this week. I'm really lucky not to have bone pain (yet) and am hiding from that gang if they try to show up! It did help this week to find out that most of the fatigue is likely caused by dropping my hemoglobin by 1/3 in 3 weeks.  I'm lucky that a friend had asked to take the kids for a day at the end of this week, so I've got 6 hours available for the transfusion.  (6 hours?!?  Is it so we can savour every drop as it goes in and admire the hue?)  I had had other plans for the day (shopping, resting, a massage?) but you know, hooking up with an IV can be fun too.  I'll be on the rheumatology ward, which will be a new experience, at the very least. To be honest, it will be the last day of the 2 week school holidays, and (did I mention that the children are hyped up on food dye and chocolate?) I may well be ready to have a day without them by that point anyhow. The chest pain is a fun symptom and I highly recommend it if anyone is feeling neglected or short of attention.  Apparently I didn't use the right code word when I saw the junior doctor last week, and he didn't react right away.  I followed up later in the appointment and he said that they don't worry unless one is short of breath.  I replied by telling him how my kids had described our latest hike up the hill to my husband, ("... and she could only go like SIX STEPS without having to stop and rest, and when we found a bench she could hardly get to it and then just SAT THERE for TEN MINUTES, and then when we moved she could STILL only go six steps before needing to catch her breath AGAIN!") (I felt like I was listening to them describe my grandmother.)  Anyhow, the nice doctor got all excited at that point, and I got the attention I crave.  I'll have an exercise ECG one of these days, but I had a resting one that day, right away.  They did say that the hemoglobin drop can put pressure on the heart too, so the body's response can be out of proportion, and getting some blood into me should help. The junior doctor (which I keep mentioning because it drives me mad to see him--everything he discusses with me then needs to be discussed with the real oncologist if I say anything interesting at all--but I don't get to be part of that conversation--he just leaves the room and returns, saying, "I've spoken to ... and they say..."  And I worry that what would be interesting to a real oncologist might not catch his attention through his juniorness), anyhow, he also told me that my hair probaby wouldn't come out any more than it had--by weeks 6 or so of Taxol people's hair comes back. (I had had 3 by that point.)  I don't think he knows carboplatin, since I've been shedding like a puppy all weekend.  My hair was firmly committed to my head on Thursday, but is quite flabby and weak in resolution  now.  Down to about 1/4 eyebrows, and hoping to go no further, but will take it as it goes! I'm glad that Easter is over.  It's a very big week in our family and I'd been dreading having the carbo plus taxol on Holy Thursday, (not least because I also had to do birthday shopping this weekend) and being knocked flat for such an important week.  We're pretty much through it now, aside from the overtired crying and bickering (and the kids are a bit off colour too!), and I'm going to generously let my husband  enjoy that aspect of the holiday while I go off and have a rest! Good luck to everyone on the Mx decisions.  It's a really hard decision to make.  I have to say that I was really happy with my reconstruction--I didn't realize how happy until I ended up with the messy scar high up on my chest and the deflated breast.  It's such a personal decision though; I sympathize with everyone trying to make it.  (I'm trying to decide if I should go for a third reconstruction--greedy, that's me!) I hope you all have a long weekend and are able to enjoy time with your families.  MaryMeg.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 04:10PM MaryMeg wrote: Hang in there, UTMom!  You are our last and will be the most special when we can officially close off on "Jan 2011 Chemo"! (Not that we'll stopposting of course!) I finished my taxol/carboplatin yesterday and am amazed at my frame of mind.  Things that I've been procrastinating on for 6 months are all done.  (Other things, like tidying my house, don't seem to be happening however, hmm.)  They were all simple things that would only take a phone call, but they involved forward planning (like having a tradesman in ) and it's like I was afraid to make any plan at all that involved a schedule, because I've been so flaky. I find it mind-boggling, because my last Taxol was YESTERDAY, so it's not like my physiology is noticeably different today than it was, oh, 3 days ago, but suddenly I feel like I'm looking forwards again, instead of treading water.  I have a weekend plan that involves having my toenails painted royal blue with sparkles, just to say "So There!" at chemo.  (Oh dear, there goes my reputation for maturity!) I had a transfusion on Monday, to try to get my hemoglobin out of the 85 range and it had an astonishing impact, much better than the last transfusion.  Pity I didn't have it before I played the piano at Mass last Saturday night.  Oops.  (It's hard to do new, complex tasks that require lots of attention sharing (watching the priest, the overheads, the person running the projector system, the music and the piano all at once) when your brain is sitting there going, "Duuuuuhhhhhh.") I was also amazed at the psychological difference.  I was SO low, for the past few weeks, and I thought it was a normal part of chemo (and I guess it sort of is) but the transfusion made it all go away, so I finished on a high.  This is good, because I'd hoped to trot gracefully across the finish line, but if not for the transfusion I'd have been one of those who staggers down to the finish, then trips and lies on the tarmac till they come with a stretcher.  Not quite the image I was hoping for. Did anyone else find that chemo just destroyed their hand?  All of mine was in my right hand, and it now looks shocking.  It's yellow and mottled with purple all across the knuckles and sides; the veins are completely munted (takes a minimum of 2 tries to find one that works), scratches no longer heal--it's a real delight to look at.  (And my platelets are now at 1/3 of normal too, (and I already had a mild clotting disorder), so I'm a wee bit paranoid about cuts!)  I have a week old cat scratch on that hand, and on Monday when I got the transfusion, they gave me a prescription for antibiotics (which I thought was ridiculous)--until I woke Tuesday morning to find it red and puffy.  I think I want a refund on that hand. Aside from that, I've been very lucky.  I had a week of the Neupogen shots a while back which also gave me a HUGE boost of energy (which is not recorded in the literature, so apparently it wasn't a real boost, just a figment, but I'll take it either way!) Next up I have rads (time to start reading again!).  I had my planning session on Monday, but they are coming up with two plans for me, one involving the mammary nodes and one not.  I'm taking the mammary one (esp after my oncologist said that if it were her, she'd insist on it), so I really hope that it doesn't involve destroying my heart and lungs to get the nodes.  That would be a nuisance!  UTMom, I don't have my eyebrows and lashes fully bck, but the lashes are definitely growing. No one can see them, but I dont'care--I know they are there!  Try feeling for them--I could feel mine before I could see them.  (All right, I still can't see them. :-)  No head hair, but the carboplatin is to blame there.  I'm still not over the thrill of having no leg hair, so I'm happy to be bald a while longer. Sorry to hear about your neutrophils, ProudMom.  I had one chemo when mine were at 600 (that ws the one where I got the shots, oddly enough).  It's a bit unnerving to have them so low, isn't it?  Glad you're able to go with the rads now.  Yorelh, I hope your drain is gone by now and your BMX recovery is good.  WIll you be having a reconstruction?  I've got a plastics appt in 10 days and need to start getting my head around my options there.  (I had a preventative BMX and TRAM reconstruction 5 years go, and my brain just can not deal with the idea of reconstructing the same breast TWICE. I hope the New Zealand public health care system can deal with it. :-) Christine, that is so cool about your hair.  I hope it improves every day! marial, everyone I've spoken to says that effects get worse for a few weeks afterwards before they improve, both with chemo and rads.  Hardly seems fair, does it?   MM, off to see if there is any food in the house that doesn't taste of metal.  (How long before food is nice again?  Anyone?)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 1, 2013 05:15PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi all, Leftfootforward, that is so nasty that your cancer progressed.  Good for you for the positivity and I really hope you manage to stomp it into submission once and for all.  I hope you've got lots of support.  It seems doubly unfair after you having to go through chemo already.  What are they hitting it with this time? Glad to hear about those whose hair is behaving.  Mine is still short--it used to grow very quickly (6" a year), so my frustration that it's still not shoulder length is huge--it was waist length (I donated 24") when all this started.  And my eyebrows look like I let a pack of 6 year olds practice waxing on them.  I have some lovely friends who are beauticians (and one who used to run Look Good Feel Better) and they have gently mentioned a few times that filling in the eyebrows would make a difference, but once again, my engineer's sense of style is taking the lead and I'm leaving them patchy. (My legs, luckily, are also patchy.  Hey, for all I know, my hair might be too, but I have so much of it, I wouldn't notice.  For the past year it has looked like nothing so much as a curly bush. Meh.  I'm hoping that the fact that I no longer feel superstitious complaining about it is a good sign.) We had a fun scare a few months ago--I got a lump on the exact site of the original tumour (Tinkerbell)--on the day of my original diagnosis-- and EVERYONE was freaking out.  The radiologist's words were "You don't have to be Einstein to know what we're seeing here," the surgeon, when I was making (nervous) small talk at the appt where I found it and asked how his day was going said, "You've ruined it thoroughly," and my pessimistic husband was possibly the least cheerful person alive.  Unfortunately, my kids are quite switched on and my 11yo girl figured it out when my husband came with me to the appointments, so we had a period of serious local panic.  Oddly, I wasn't panicking.  I knew which way the odds were tipped, but I'm not  one to count chickens early and I've had a few very unlikely events recently (in addition to getting cancer AFTER having my breasts removed, I won a travel prize of $100k of flights a year ago.  How cool is that?)  So to cut a long story a bit shorter, it was a false alarm, but it was quite tense.  Not least because all the hospital oncologists went away just as the results were ready to a conference and were planning to make me wait 2 weeks fo results that were ready in 3 days.  I ended up getting in touch with the office of the New Zealand Health and Disability Commissioner and they got in touch with the hospital and they worked out a way for me to get the results without having my hand held by the surgeon at the time.  (The hospital was insistent that the results would need to go through the multi-disciplinary committee first;  I was insistent that they were my results and I had a right to them as soon as they were available!  (Watching my daughter and husband bravely mope was starting to put me off my food.) Even if that wasn't enough of a wake-up call to count my blessings, a good friend died last week.  She was within 6 months of my age, and her cancer had metastisized when it was found.  She had a very good run (and NZ has a fabulous group called Sweet Louise that takes care of women with metastatic BC), but it is still sobering. I hope that everyone we haven't heard of is staying well.  I'd love to hear how everyone is doing.   MM, who had been a bit casual about the tamoxifen until October but I am quite careful about it now. :-)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 02:48AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi everyone! I'm new here and am also starting chemo in January--in 4 days in fact. I've had rather a long wait for the chemo (I'm in New Zealand and  there is a shortage of oncologists in Wellington at the moment), so I'm very keen to get started. I'm a statistical anomaly in lots of ways.  I'm BRCA1 (which is not very common); I had a double prophylactic mastectomy 4 years ago to ensure that I didn't get breast cancer, but I got it anyhow (which is particularly uncommon!) and my cancer is ER+, which is also very uncommon for those of us who are BRCA1.  From now on I'd like to just play the odds and beat this thing! I'm looking forward to getting to know the others who will be going through chemo at the same time as me, and working out how to cope best.  I'm having AC (doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide), followed by taxol/carboplatin. (The carboplatin is because of the BRCA1 mutation, and just to make chemo more fun!)  I do have a question, for those of you who know more about this than I do--with AC chemo, how long is it likely to be before I lose my hair?  I've got a rather thick mane of it (which I gather means that it will fall out quickly when it starts to go--the weight of it will pull it out), and I'd like to be prepared.  Mary Margaret, feeling like I should be introducing myself as though I've just joined a country club. :-)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 02:27PM MaryMeg wrote: They use the abdominus rectus muscle (the six-pack muscles that I wasn't using. :-) and take them ant your tummy fat.  The fat makes the new breast shape, and the muscle provides the blood supply for it.  A free TRAM lifts the whole thing up and moves it, hence the re-connecting blood vessels etc. They essentially take a wedge from your tummy, and since in my case I went from convex to concave, that wedge, when it was sewn up again, left me bent over for a while.  I can do back bends again though now, so it does pass! They do cut little circles out of the wedge they remove to use for the nipples, which means that until (if) you get tattoos, they are a slightly different colour! I had no screening (nothing much to screen).  The lump was in the upper middle corner of my right breast--a spot with almost no tissue out of it.  I think of it as removing the stuffing from a pillow, and missing a couple bits of fluff in the corners.  We knew that not all the cells could be removed and I was just unlucky!  I found it because it was a bump, and I scratched it and thought, Hmm...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 10:20PM MaryMeg wrote: I'm so glad to have all you guys out there--I'm already worried about using up the local sympathy and I've only had 2 x AC so far! Re wigs, I went to a local lady with a great eye.  Even when I had my thick mane, she picked a Raquel Welch wig for me and it's turned out great.  A new acquaintance, who knew I had BC and who works with Look Good, Feel Better still didn't believe it was a wig.  yay!  (I think it's the "classic" style or something like that--very boring, very different from my old long hair and easy.)  I'm glad I went with synthetic as it's just the level of maintenance I do on myself--none. (Hence the old mane.) My mum's wig (20 years ago) looked like a dead possum though, so my standards weren't high going into this.  Now if LGFB (on Friday) can convince me that makeup is worth it, they will deserve a medal! Sorry to hear about the SEs that are still piling up and about the hospital visit, hsgray.   It takes special luck to have your treatment affected by Egypt too!  I hope things get better. How many of us have blood draws between treatments?  We just have it done the day before the next one.  I scraped through and am a wee bit nervous of not making it next time. My SE have gone up this time.  Manageable nausea, but insane fatigue.  Everytime there is a good chance (and sometimes without one), I just drop into my glassy-eyed fish on a platter routine.  Today 2 of my kids started school (at different times, in different places, one at a new school, of course), and I felt like I was in a comedy routine.  Send child out door.  Flop onto bed.  Leap out of bed at alarm, plop possum on head, make chitty-chat to other new parents, drive home, seal door, debone onto bed again.  My youngest, who had unlimited computer time while I was doing my dead fish routine, thought he had gone to heaven (although he was disappointed that we didn't go geocaching or bowling as we'd hoped to). Made it through the pickups, the swimming lesson, and more chit-chat with new teachers, then let my 12yo make carbonara again (4th time since I started chemo :-).  Am going to have to work out how to look more languid and Garbo and less grey and glassy! Anyone else finding the steroids filling them like a vase?  I finished my steroids (mexadethasone) for round 2 on Sunday and last night (Monday night) I was up to the loo about 900 times.  No wonder we're on water restrictions around here--I was hogging it all.  I didn't know that was an SE, but it it's not, then I'm not just turning into a fish, but a fish bowl as well.  Hmm. This was day 6 for me, so I'm hoping for a gradual turnaround starting tomorrow, when child #3 also starts school and the other 2 get themselves there and home without help.  I have leftovers thawing (a phrase to cheer any family) so I plan to sleep the whole 6 hours they are out of the house tomorrow if I need to (and I expect to need to!) (If I'm not heard from again, interrogate my cats...)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 09:49PM MaryMeg wrote: Another positive for me is that I got flooded with flowers for my birthday. :-)  Very very lovely.  Sherry, I agree about telling your daughter.  Thinking of it from her point of view, if my mother had a life threatening illness like cancer and didn't tell me, I would assume that that meant I meant so very little to her that she didn't even think I needed to know.  You know, in the same category as gas station attendants and clerks at the supermarket.  I would feel rejected to my core if my mother had done that--even if it was meant to protect me.  (And I speak as one who briefly considered not telling my husband the biopsy results because he was in Singapore at the time and I didn't want to worry him--until I thought about how I'd feel if he did that to me.) Kids are very very hard sometimes. Webu, how amazing that your daughter came around like that.  One of my brothers was heading off the rails when my mum got cancer and he turned completely around too.  (A counsellor said that it is a fairly common bargaining strategy.  I don't mind--I'm just glad it happened!)

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 02:11PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi Everyone! I'm baaaack!  I've been reading all the postings but haven't had much time/energy for posting myself.  I had my 2nd AC 2 weeks ago and found it much more tiring than the first one.  Am more or less back to normal, but keep getting whacked by the "Take A Nap" bus.  Last night I pushed through (at least till dinner was made), then ended up in bed with chills, hot, chills, hot.  A wee bit scary.  Just before that I got a massive headache and took Tylenol, so I don't know what that did to any fever.  My normal, evening baseline temperature (which the cancer nurse got me to make sure I know) is 96 degrees (35.5C), so even when I was burning up, my temperature only got to about 97.3 (after the TYlenol.)  I knew it was way up on normal, my husband knew it was way up, but we also both knew that no one was likely to take it seriously when it was below what it normally should be!  Luckily I'm fine this morning, (and temp is 36/96.8) but we were both quite worried.  (DH kept muttering "sepsis!" under his breath to cheer me up.) I was planning to go to a funeral this morning--the only child, 18 months old, of an acquaintance,-- but as every preschooler in New Zealand (and their parents) will be there, after last night I am staying away. I too found the second round of AC a bit rough and am glad there are only 2 more.  I've heard from several friends that weekly Taxol is much easier, esp once the AC is out of our systems. I'mnot going to be doing it weekly (since I'm adding carboplatin to the Taxol), but will give updates from The Land of Platinum Chemo once that starts. Have been watching tons of DVDs, mostly old episodes of THE WEST WING. I love watching on a laptop!  Am very grateful for the tip on the lint roller.  I'm starting my second shedding and am looking forward to getting rid of most of what remains.  I'd also love to lose my sideburns, but my hair is a bit longer (it was a #4, a month ago) so they aren't as obvious. Star Trek sucks me in (I'm a certifiable geek) as does anything before 1965--the older the better.  (Had my 7 year old asking to watch NORTH BY NORTHWEST and HIGH NOON recently.  Get them early, that's my philosophy!) Jean, thanks for the suggestion on the decadron.  I only get 2 pills though, so not sure what to do.  Will ask onco. Am very happy with my wig.  A number of people have told me it's the best they've ever seen, and 2 have told me it makes me look 10 years younger!  Best part of all?  My 10 year old daughter presented with lice this week and I don't have to worry about getting them! (That was always my nightmare.)  Yay!  (Lots of mother/daughter bonding time in progress.)  I've got some lovely hats and scarfs, but they aren't getting any use at the moment.  Partly that's because at home I go commando if the wig is annoying (only by the end of the day). I'm curious about why people are using shampoo on mostly hairless heads?  ('m just using the Dove soap I use on the rest of me and am enjoying the liberation.  My husband, who sports a #2 most of the time, uses expensive shampoo and conditioner and I just don't get it.  I had "Pantene Girl" hair, so it made sense to me.  He has "sea captain" hair (and beard), so I can't see why he'd bother! Emily, I hoe the shedding goes okay.  I found it really useful to have a buzz cut when that happened--shedding tiny hairs wasn't nearly as traumatic, but the buzz still covered my head so I didn't feel bald right away.  (Where in Ontario are you?  I'm from Toronto.) Sherry, that's wonderful about your daughter.  I hope that youfind yourselves coming back together as you work through this! Like a few of us, I'm dreading #3 AC next week, but am glad that AC will be 3/4 done.  Have decided not to fast, just as a data point, to see if it was making a difference.  I'm also a bit worried about WBC, and would hate to fast for 2 days and then be deferred!  I have the 3 weekdays between now and then full of appointments for kids and pets, and have grand plans for cooking and freezing gourmet meals.  (That's not going to happen, but I like planning. :-)  Good luck, everyone--hang in there!

I also finished AC#4 yesterday and am safely tucked away at my weekend meeting.  I've managed it well.  I went to the gym at 5:45 this morning, baked, got the kids to school, took the train to my meeting (hooray for yesterday's steroids for the energy), met everyone and participated in a lengthy and creative introductory process (we make decisions by consensus so group building at the start is REALLY important), had lunch, and then slept for the entire afternoon session.  (You know, when they were actually WORKING.)  Woke for dinner, got briefed on the afternoon and am now tucked away in bed (mostly avoiding images from Japan)  I'm hoping that if I sleep till breakfast tomorrow, I might be able to be part of the work, but if not que sera sera, and I'll not fret if fatigue/nausea drive me off! Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 01:44AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi baf4292 and starella,  I'm the one who decided to try fasting, but there's not much evidence to support it yet. I don't know if any of you know of the studies that have found that people who eat way fewer calories than normal (like half or less), tend to live a very long time?  It's been reproduced in mice, particularly, and their cells work like ours in lots of ways.  Some of those scientists were looking at why this happens, and they've found that fasting (in mice) causes cells to go into a sort of protective mode that is almost dormant, and keeps cells from dying at the normal rate.  They wondered how that would work with cancer, and found that FOR MICE, if you starved/fasted the mouse, the normal cells were protected 1000-fold from the effects of chemo, while the cancer cells were killed off at the normal rate. (Cancer cells are well known for not following instructions, so in this case, they didn't go dormant, but kept partying.)  Again, this is in mice; there are no full studies of this in humans.  Normally all cells in our body are equally vulnerable to chemo, but in the mice research, they found that only 1 normal cell would die for every 1000 cancer cells that were killed by the chemo.  (The implication is that if this does work, you could really ramp up the chemo doses without hurting your patients, since right now the limit on chemo doses is the damage done to normal cells.) There has been a human case study (published in a journal on aging (I assume because these scientists are mostly studying cell aging and death) www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20... looking at a very small number of people, and they found that it looked promising and seemed to reduce side effects quite a lot for some of them.  Because what little data there is seemed to offer benefit and no loss of effect for the chemo, and since it was a peer-reviewed study in a real journal (and reported in New Scientist) I decided to try it, and I've had very few ill effects from the chemo (but I've had lots of anti-emetics too--so who knows). I want to emphasize though: 1) I was trying it without it being through any medical process--it was purely my own reading of the research (although I was a scientist before I had kids) and it wasn't suggested by any doctor. In fact, my oncologist was away the day I started chemo and doesn't know yet! 2) While the research looks good so far, there is very very little of it, so there could be important stuff (good or bad) that we don't know, and I'd hate anyone to think I was suggesting they try it. We think that the cancer is killed off by the chemo just as well in this situation, but there is too little evidence yet to say for sure. The only way to know for sure is proper clinical trials, and they haven't been done. 3) It only works if the fasting is long enough for the cells to shut down into the protective mode (ie. 48 hours or longer before the chemo).  Again, people's doctors are not likely to suggest that as a routine idea. (I only managed 43 hours (I forgot to stop eating :-) ), and I don't know if that had any effect. Again, and I hate to harp but I have to say it, this was me (not a doctor) weighing up the science on my own behalf and deciding to take the risk that the benefits would outweigh the negatives, but there is so little evidence (however promising that little is), that if anyone wants to try it, please discuss it with someone who can read the paper and help you come to an informed decision--don't take my word for it, please! I did discuss it with others who have science backgrounds to make sure we all had the same take on it, but I'm annoying to argue with (being part bulldog) and I'm not sure how hard they'd have tried to talk me out of it. :-)  (And that said, I'm not one for complementary or alternative treatments normally and am pretty scientific/rigorous in my outlook, but again, the only person I was risking here was me!) I hope that gives you more information, anyhow! There is another writeup in press at the moment by some of the same authors, bt it hasn't been published yet--they're just teasing us with the abstract (somewhere--I've lost it).   MM, who was amazed at how easy and non-traumatic the fasting was.  Normally going without a snack finishes me off! (Probably it counteracted the adrenaline of the first chemo panicking!)

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 01:30PM MaryMeg wrote: Temperature?  AimeeMac, your comment about breaking into a sweat reminded me, is anyone else finding temperature regulation really odd?  I hadn't realized until now how hard our bodies work to keep us feeling normal while things around us change--till it stopped working.  I find that now, if I have a cup of tea, I suddenly get so hot I have to open the window.  Or if I have a cold drink I need to put a sweater on.  It only lasts a few minutes, but the most trivial changes (cat in a lap, standing over the stove, being near an open window, (it's a cool summer here) make me suddenly very hot or very cold.  Then I get over it--until I get a hug and break into a sweat.  Very odd! (And menopause was 6 years ago, so that's not it!)   MM, very confused (not that that is noteworthy :-)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 01:41PM MaryMeg wrote: islandmom, I'm with you on the exercise.  I've always exercised intermittently (probably twice week would have been what I managed), but I am focussing on at least 30 minutes of serious exercise a day now, preferably an hour.   I gather it takes 3 weeks to make it  a habit.  I know from experience that after 3 weeks of decent exercise I will start to crave it instead of having to drag myself up to it. I'm committing to 3 gym classes a week (M,W,F at 6am, before my husband goes to work (since it's summer holidays here)) and am going fo a run on the other days.  Having the routine of those classes makes it all more structured, and I'm someone who needs structure! I'm letting myself have one day a week off, but only one and most weeks I'm going right through.  I find it kind of funny that since starting chemo I've become noticeably more muscular. :-) I'm also trying o get hold of my oncologist (not easy as she is a locum) to get switched to DD AC (clearly it's not going to happen this round, but I'll have 6 chemos after it), AND change the protocol she suggested for AIs.  I have a chance to nail this cancer and am marshalling every resourse I can onto it!   (Not that my BRCA1 status and the fact that I got cancer even after prophylactic mastectomies has made me at all paranoid, really!) PS vis0121 I really hope you got some help with the nausea.  Who did you speak to?  What did they offer?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 12:25AM - edited Jan 23, 2011 12:30AM by MaryMeg Hi everyone, Just wanted to say hello--I feel like I've been in the wilderness thanks to that silly survey that locked me out no matter what I clicked on.  I tried three browsers and my phone (and cleared caches etc etc).  I'm glad they finally fixed it.  At least I was getting the updates via email or I'd have been in hospital for withdrawal instead of cancer! I'm glad to hear that those of us with the worst SE seem to be getting over the hump.  Here's hoping the next lot doesn't hit anyone quite so hard.  At least we'll each know more of what to expect. I got a buzz cut on Tuesday, (day 13) to ensure that my hair didn't fall out before I donated it.  The ponytail was exactly 24", which was cool.  Friday night I noticed that my remaining was starting to come out a bit easily (but I was still happy going around on Saturday with just the #4), but last night (Saturday here) it started coming out by the handful.  Or what would have been the handful had it been more than 1/2" long.  Fingerful?  Several times today I've locked myself in the bathroom and gone through it with a fine-toothed comb with a bit of tension on it, and about 80% of the hair is now gone.  I'm not nearly as scary looking bald as I'd feared, although at the moment I think my look is more "advanced mange" rather than "bald".  Would love to know how to get that shiny look on my pate (although I fear the children will draw on it while I'm napping if it's too attractive-looking). A/C #2 for me later this week, and I'm going to try fasting again, so I need to get the kids making up the "No eating, Mummy!" signs soon again!  (I tend to forget quite easily!) I hope everyone is feeling well mentally, even while this disease and its treatment puts our bodies through the wringer!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 08:38PM MaryMeg wrote: Julie, I've been posting on facebook about using sticky tape to make patterns on the back of my head.  My very helpful friends, clearly not understanding the reverence due to a Woman With Cancer, have been making suggestions on what patterns we should make with the tape, hence my concerns about the children painting my head--I think my friends are out buying paint! I was reading at church yesterday and my helpful daughter wanted me to sticky tape off a cross so that the congregation could see it when I left the lectern. I declined.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 10:02PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi lorenar, and welcome!  I'm very sorry you have to be here, but glad you've found us.  It's really great if you have a place where you can try wigs on--it's amazing how different they look on us, than on the stand!  I hope you don't get hit too hard by the chemo.  What type are you having? Anniemomofthree, I'm actually just pretending to be a Kiwi.  I'm really a Canadian (and married to an Aussie, so I lived there for 7 years too.)  I am thoroughly confused as to nationality now, but I am absolutely multinational when it comes to junk food! Oreos, Nanaimo bars, Tim Tams, doughnuts, hot dogs, trifle, butter tarts, pavlova, brownies--I feel it's my duty to ensure that my children can eat unhealthily in any culture!     MM, not sure that leading up to my fasting with two bowls of trifle was helping the cause (but it was sure yummy).
