Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 08:34PM MaryMeg wrote: SSIrish, lovely to meet you but so sorry we're here! My treatment is similar to yours but not exactly the same.  I've got 4xAC, then Taxol+Carboplatin., then rads, then AIs until I get sick of the side effects. :-)  Sad that your second treatment was on your 47th birthday. Mine is tomorrow (the treatment) and my 47th birthday is next Friday--the day I go to Look Good, Feel Better.  That will be my treat to myself--to finally learn how to put on makeup.  (I wonder if I can score some tanning cream for my ghoul-like skull?) I'd heard that cooling our hands and feet help with the neuropathy.  There are alsoa few things we can take, like B6.  I need to read up on that before the end of March, for sure! Anniemomofthree, Science girl and anyone else who really suffered this time around, I hope the oncologists get it better for you on this next round.  Fingers crossed!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 11:42PM MaryMeg wrote: Nanaimo bars:  (I have my priorities)  Thanks for posting it AimeeMac.  My internet was flaky at the hospital and it was driving me mad not being able to post it.  THey are a three layer slice, with a chocolate/crumb/coconut base, a middle that is butter and icing sugar, and a thin dark chocolate top. My recipe has no cooking at all--you just mix the first lot of ingredients.  (You can melt the butter if you want, or cream it with the cocoa and egg.  Until very recently I never saw the instructions to cook the base--am assuming that's a raw egg thing.  I've always used raw egg and never had a problem.)  The original recipes also called for unsweetened chocolate, which provides a cool contrast to the very sweetness of the rest. Here's a link with a picture. http://www.joyofbaking.com/NanaimoBars.html ProudMom So glad your husband sees it that way and is supporting you.  Take care of yourself! navywife :  That is awfully scary to be BRCA1 and have 4 children.  How many are girls?  I'm 46 and just Dx (My mum and their sisters were 48, 50 and 52 and two of them died).  I worry a lot about my 10 year old daughter, especially since the kids (I also have 7 and 12 year old boys) all get genetics and that she is particularly at risk.  At least it's not BRCA2, so the boys won't get BC! You join me in the "unusual" category--we're both ER+, which isn't common with BRCA1.  Yay, us! What is your chemo?  My oncologist added carboplatin to my AC+T (making it AC+PT) because of the BRCA1 and because we don't beat ER+ as well as non-BRCA people. It's hard not to worry about those  stories you hear, but I find it best to just focus on the odds.  Finding it early hugely increases your chances.  Being Stage I is the best possible stage, and you're not TN, which gives more options.  By far the most likely scenario is that you will be fine.  Hang in there!  bdavis, are you also BRCA1? I am a HUGE believer in mastectomies for BRCA carriers, although the risk reduction is lower after a Dx, I believe.  I did it myself 4 years ago, but I was one of the very rare cases where the few remaining cells still went feral.   (And they DIED for it, so there!) Even so, it was in an easy to catch place, and I don't have to live with the "what if" of not doing it and then thinking I could have avoided the place I'm in.  I have an advanced degree in Maternal Guilt, so I'm glad that source of guilt is denied me.  Navywife, I can't believe yours went feral at 29.  That's awful.  How old were other family members?  I didn't even really worry till I was close to 40. lorenar, I'm glad you're feeling better (and sorry that day 1 was so hard).  Good for you on walking the dog!  ScienceGirl, how are you doing with the hair loss?  I wasn't as upset as I'd feared, but mine was very very short by then, which had a very different emotional impact.  It tended to squick those around me though. I hope everyone is well.  Who are the next of us to have The Chair?   MM, whose AC#2 today was very relaxing, except when the internet failed.  I fasted again (but will try #3 without it, just to see if it makes a difference).  Am so looking forward to breakfast. (Yay, steroids!)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 11:14PM MaryMeg wrote: CityKitty, I just sent you a PM to see if you did the half-marathon.  How did you feel afterwards?  I love that distance but it will be a fair while before I'm up for it again.  What kind of time do you consider "slow?" (I love marathoners--some consider anything below qualifying for Boston as "slow" while others are happy to make it in under 7 hours, before the roads are opened for traffic again. :-) Amazing that you did that.   I was lucky with the hair loss--because I donated mine, my daughter nagged me to cut it before any came out.  It was really really good for me to have the buzz, because I liked how it looked (which I didn't expect), and when it came out, having these tiny hairs all over didn't feel like "losing my hair" in the way that having great long locks all over the place would have.  Good luck with yours--it's a challenge, that's for sure.  UTMom, good luck with the Neulasta.  My counts were very borderline for m chemo yesterday (Neutrophils 1.1, with  1.0 cutoff and WBC 2.8 with a 3.0 cutoff (i.e. I should have failed).  I'm not getting Neulasta this time (yay!) but if I fail next time (which will be gutting) I will.  Have to admit, I've been very slack about infection because I've felt so great.  I even took my 7yo to the after hours medical clinic the other night and then stole a baby (she was grizzling and her grandma had clearly had enough, and I worked ina preschool for 8 years and have The Touch).  Well the baby vomited all over grandma when I gave her back--I'm glad I wasn't holding her and didn't end up in hospital!  (Would have been a very embarrassing explanation--I did know better, really!) Lucky husband can take kids to the ER if it's needed from now on! jcoutee, I totally understand on the BRCA thing.  It would be so nice to know why you've been hit like this at such an unusually young age.  On the other hand, at least you don't have to make decisions about having your ovaries out.  And the risk of contralateral (other breast) cancer for BRCA1 types is 28%, so you're spared that too.  Now you just need to get rid of what you've got and you should be okay!  I don't worry much because I've had the mastectomies--I figure I'mnot likely to get unrelated cancers, but if I hadn't had the mastectomies, the risk of cancer after cancer is just so high.  Yick. Julie, thanks for the reminder about steroids and emotions.  My kids were wild today--and I'm sure that is why.  Oops.  I've been popping in and out of my husband's study all evening just to share tidbits as I tidy through my paperwork basker and he finally followed me out to the kitchen to tell me how hard it is for him when I'm in this stressed out frame of mind.  I thought I was on the cheerful and happy end of normal, but I think I was probably closer to that wild-eyed cheer that sends people backing carefully out of the room.  Oops. We don't have wifi, but my phone tethers my laptop to the internet--except the latest update on the phone has it crashing all the time.  Bleah. I sympathise on the "I totally understand what you're going through" thing.  When my dad died, when my brother was 18, a teacher of his told me that he "understood completely" because his favourite uncle had died a few years ago.  Now the teacher was quite young, and in retrospect he probably did really get it if he'd been very close to the uncle, but I remember how disgusted our whole family was that he, at the elderly age of 28 or so, could have ANY idea what it felt like to lose your father at 18.  For some reason I don't mind it as much if they say "I've been there".  Because that's more about the general situation and not our emotions and our specifics. Full sympathy to those of you dealing with the snow days.  It would drive me mad to never know from one day to the next if school would be on or off or delayed or what.  And getting phone calls at 5am would not help! Welcome Nancy!  Sorry you're here, but it hope it all goes well.  I'm the same as you for the Tx, except my taxol will include carboplatin.  We're the unusual ones, getting it 3 weekly! I hope everyone is well. How are people feeling in general now that we're mostly getting into the routine of all this?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 01:56AM MaryMeg wrote: EmilyinOntario, my hair had a day or two (day 17 was the main one) where the hair was just coming out all the time if I touched it.  I had a buzz cut by then, so no handfuls, but lots of teeny tiny dark hairs all over the place.  (Am still finding them on my computer--I think some went inside to hide and are still emerging).  It was only for those 2 days or so though.  After that, what was left has stayed so far. I've reached that same number of daysafter AC #2 now (I'm half way through my 4xAC every 3 weeks) but the remaining hairs are hanging tight.  Not sure how I feel about that.  On the one hand, if I'm allowed do the the total-hairs-end-to-end thing, I'm going to have more hair than my husband again soon. (He's not allowed to count his beard)  OTOH, I'd like to be either bald or normal.  Right now I feel like I'm auditioning for the part of a middle-aged newborn baby.  Are they going to re-run Mork and Mindy?  I could do the Jonathan Winters part! Lots of sympathy for those with tender scalps.  I'm lucky; mine tingled on about day 5 after #1, but nothing at all since then.  Carla, the leg lesions sound awful.  Have others had that?  I totally sympathize on feeling like life is totally unpredictable.  I'm like that too.  I'm 16 days after AC#2, and should be perfectly fine, but still have no idea what I'll be able to do.  Today my husband arranged for us to go on a hike with some colleagues of his (and our children; 7, 10 and 12).  It was up and down some hills, about 6k in total distance; took us about 2.5 hours, including a break.  I was half-expecting to be shattered by it and spend the rest of the day in bed.  Instead I spent the rest f the day cleaning the house, buying groceries, and cooking. No crash at all.  On the other hand, 40 minutes before we went this morning, I was tottering off to the sofa to lie immobile for 20 minutes (trying not to panic at the thought of the possible ordeal that lay ahead).  It drives me mad not to know. I worry that my friends will think I'm a drama queen--constantly warning them that I may not be able to make things (only to then show up, perky and apparently fine)--while on the other hand, everyone else is thinking me unreliable as I promise to do easy things on what will be good days, only to end up doing the floppy fish instead.  (At least back in my youth when I phoned in sick I was able to fake sounding sick.  I hve no idea what faking In Cancer's Clutches would look like.  I supposed I could just take the wig off and flash my Darth Vader skull at them.)   Which is  long way of saying that some consistency and predictability would be welcomed! Have now been told by 4 unrelated people that the wig makes me look "10 years younger".  Am carefully not asking "Younger than what?" Am assuming that I now look a sprightly 37, not that I previously looked like an old hag with a young girl's hair.  Sherry, I've also been amazed at how survivors have reached out.  This week I got a card from the woman who last year taught recorder at my children's school.  She has moved away since then (I assume in response to the trauma of attempting to instill music into my 7 year old) and didn't put an address on the card, but "wanted to encourage" me.  People are so lovely. baf4292, I hope your arm gets better quickly.  I'm on AC and was given serious warnings about that--the adriamycin in particular has a terrible reputation for destroying tissue.  Our hospital does it as a "slow push" (I can not tell you the images in my mind until I saw what they really meant by it!) so that they can monitor it going in.  This is scary stuff they are putting into us! Amy, thanks to the link to your blog (and for the photo of the lovely Millie).  Don't feel a wimp at all--the combination of what we're going through and the way it drains us of energy and resilience makes it awfully hard to keep going.  We can make it though--one day at a time is all we need to face.  (My mum was diagnosed with Stage IV Ovarian CA and I remember her saying that she'd rather die than finish her first round of chemo.  She did finish it though--and then did two more sets of chemo later.  That was a real lesson to me of how people can hang on through things they never thought they could do.)  I do agree with you though--chemo is barbaric! It's nice to be able to vent to each other too.  Sometimes just saying how I feel helps me get past the feeling.  (Unfortunately, today's salient feeling--like all my clothes are getting too tight--seems unlikely to vanish through expressing it.  Darn.) How many of us sleep commando?  I bought a few pretty caps, including a "Night Before Christmas" style red night-cap which I love, to wear in bed, but I feel like a dork wearing a hat in bed.  Particularly when my husband happily sleeps in his half-bald, half-buzz cut head without any need for headgear.  Luckily the family has the good manners to not shriek when they see me bald(ish), and I quite like the feeling of the wind whistling through my sparse hair! (It was hysterical on the hike today--it was a really warm day, and I kept dropping behind so I could lift up my wig and get some airflow--I felt as surreptitious as a flasher, or someone trying to hawk stolen watches.  Anyone who saw me would have thought I was smuggling something up there, the way I was acting. Am not sure what I could smuggle between a wig and my scalp.  Bra halves? Carla, I am concerned that you were not told that we Must Have Goals.  Apparently Having Goals is what cures us of this disease--the treatment is just a decoy.  If you're not planning on doing the Hawaii Ironman, a PhD in neurobiology, a quick trip up Everest, and curing ingrown toenails, then you are Letting The Side Down.  The idea that it's enough to grit our teeth through the treatment, while taking pleasure in the little things like the kindnesses of those we love, seems to be out of fashion.  My goal (shared so that you can plan your own) is to rack up as many floppy fish hours on the sofa as possible.  Double points for having the TV or video on at the time (although I often  just listen, so as not to prematurely wear out my vision on all the movies I plan to watch while in floppy fish pose). Sometimes I sleep and take it in subliminally.  This is a serious Goal I am engaged in and I don't want to burn out early.  I hope you're paying attention and planning your own Goals. Hang in there, everyone!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 12:59AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi everybody! Sorry for being AWOL.  I feel like the number of hours in a day is so very short now, what with all the napping, and I'm just not getting to all the things I want to be doing.  On the positive side, my cats now believe that I have become a cat, as my activity to nap ratio is rapidly approaching theirs, and they now follow me from room to room and nap alongside me.  Their hair is longer, however, so my husband can still tell us apart. I have my last AC (#4) on Thursday, and will be glad to have it done, although I'm very nervous about the weekly Taxol+carboplatin that will follow it.  I can't find anyone doing weekly carbo, so I'm not sure what to expect. I'm very well, aside from the napping.  I'm still going to the gym every day and am sure I'm fitter than when I started chemo (not that that would be difficult).  I'm looking around for a half-marathon for the end of the year, as I should be able to manage one by then if things do improve after the chemo.  (Failing that, I'm hoping to find a staged race with naps embedded in the race.  Anyone know of a Sleeping Beauty Half-marathon?) My big preoccupation lately (besides napping) is the earthquake in Christchurch.  It's the worst disaster to ever hit New Zealand, and it has essentially destroyed our second-biggest city.   While in nearly every respect we're a normal, affluent Western country, we are a TINY western country, and i just can't see how a country with only 4 million people can absorb an earthquake that has caused the destruction of 1/3 of the buildings in the downtown, 10,000 homes etc.  I'm involved in an early childhood service  and we have 42 centres in the city, so even though I've been on leave, I'm aware of the impact. 20% of the people in Chch have had no sewage--for two full weeks. Many have also been without water or power for that length of time.  (At least Katrina didn't destroy the sewage pipes--they'll take months or longer to put back together)   It's just unimaginable.  And of course, on top of everything, the aftershocks are constant.  No wonder 80,000 people have left the city so far. http://www.geonet.org.nz/earthquake/quakes/recent_quakes.html I'm watching this weekend approach with a sense of bemusement.  Did I mention that my last AC is on Thursday?  Well somehow I have committed to go away for the weekend on Friday.  (Some people go through chemo as Superwoman; I'm going as StupidWoman.)  I'm the national vice president of my early childhood service (we have 500 centres altogether) and each year we have two semi-annual national meetings, plus a conference.  I missed th last meeting, because it was the weekend of my diagnosis.  This is the next one, and it's here in my town, 15 minutes from home, so I thought I'd go.  I expect I will sleep nearly the whole weekend, but I reckon that any time I do wake up, I can go visit everyone else. And if they really need me for anything, they can text me and I can interrupt my nap.  (That's scenario one.  Scenario two would be that my oncologist wants me to take the steroids, in which case I will not sleep at all on the weekend and they will end up regretting telling me where they were meeting because I never shut up all weekend long.)  We shall see.  I really want to be there though, because next year I'll be president, and having missed most of this year isn't really great preparation for that. My biggest fear for the weekend is that I'll forget the ondansetron at home! Second biggest fear is that I'll forget to wear possum and the delegates will all be traumatized by the sight of my bald head.   (Third biggest fear is what the kitchen will look like by the time I get back.  Can kids get scurvy in 2 days?)  I was wondering about the Claritin that people are taking--is that just for the neulasta shot, or do some take it with Taxol too?   I am making a list of questions about the TC chemo for my oncologist, and I'm aware of the various things people are taking (e.g. l-creatinine for neuropathy) and I really struggle with my desire to not appear flaky and gullible to my oncologist, but am balancing that against my desire to not look like my hands and feet are gangrenous.  And *I* know that the B6 and l-creatinine aren't flaky ideas, but there's no guarantee that the oncologist won't think so.  My husband went through med school and I'm very aware that in some areas they appear to deposit information in the med student's head and then weld the head shut to keep anything else out. At home, I find it entertaining when we are discussing things and I come up against a welded-shut area of brain, but I'm not so enthusiastic when it's my doctor.  (This is not because I ignore my husband's opinions, really.  I promise.  Possibly it's because I feel free to mock my poor husband, but  I am not sure that is a wise approach for my doctor.) I've been reading avidly and am so glad to hear of so many of us getting through this round of chemo.  I hope we stick together through the next treatments, even if it's not chemo!  Sending lots of supportive thoughts to you all--it's great to be in such a wonderful group of women! (And now I'm off for a nap, I think. :-)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 06:38PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi Melissa,  I agree that it sounds like AC is hard core next to Taxol alone.  Chilling water (or sucking ice) helped me sometimes, but not always.  The warmer the water the yuckier.  I had plain salted crackers for the sake of having something in my tummy, and I also had peanut M&Ms around.  Letting the tummy be really empty was a problem.  The steroids were what did my moods in with AC.  I cut back on them, and I was much more pleasant to my family, luckily. My nurse said to eat whatever I wanted, and I found myself craving things that were hot, salty, fatty and not hugely flavourful--like grilled cheese, buttered toast, etc. I did find the AC cumulative, and my last dose was much harder than the first.  Good thing there are so few of them!   Good luck managing with the kids; that would be the hardest part.  The more rest I got the better I felt.   Mary Meg.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 01:39PM MaryMeg wrote:  Amara, tissue expanders are to make a space for the implants to go, if you're having implants.  The other option is to use your own tissue, through a TRAM or DIEP reconstruction (or a few others).  There is a fabulous book by Kathy Seligo called THE BREAST RECONSTRUCTION BOOK that talks a lot about the options.  I'm thinking of having the lat flap type of "own tissue" reconstruction, but am concerned that it seems to offer the worst of both worlds--huge surgery with massive recovery AND implants!  I have a lot of questions for my PS when I meet him in 6 weeks! Shelly, will you be able to ask for something like Ativan to help relax you?  It sounds like that pre-stuff is not a lot of fun.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 01:50PM MaryMeg wrote: Can we say "hat trick"? My last two really horrible chemos (as opposed to Taxol on its own, which isn't bad for me), were very bad timing.  Easter weekend (nothing like doing the whole thing of going to church on Thursday, Friday, Saturday night for 3 hours and then Sunday morning as wel (since youngest child couldn't stay up long enough on Saturday night) AND Easter baskets and hiding them and hiding eggs etc etc etc, while feeling utterly awful), and then for the last one my husband went to Oz for his sister's 50th for 3 days, so I had the whole weekend, including 2 soccer games in the rain, all on my own, with no chance to rest between 6:30am and 8:30pm. I was really looking forward to this last one being "normal" again (whatever that is), so that I could just rest for 4 days.  Guess who found out yesterday that my youngest has the day off school the day after chemo for a teachers' only day AND my husband is going on a business trip as well?  (DH has offered to cancel the business trip, but he rarely has them and it's an important one.)  I have bitten the bullet and invited my son's best friend over for the Friday as well (since his mum is a teacher and will be struggling to figure otu what to do with him on a day when she's at school)--at least it reduces the odds of me yelling at my boy when I'm feeling awful!  I'll take steroids one last time to help me get through it, I guess, plus increasing my patronage of Coca Cola Corporation.  (Just keep saying, "Last one, last one, last one" (of the icky ones anyhow!)) I feel like I should go to bed today, now, even though I'm feeling fine, just because I can.  Sort of a "Nyah, nyah, watch me rest WHEN I WANT TO!" at the universe. I'm doubly disappointed because it is a long weekend, and I'd been planning to get away at least overnight with my DH and the kids, but there is no point if I'm in the state I'll be in!  Phooey.   MM, who should start reading the rads boards so I'll be able to prepare some new ideas for things to whine about once chemo is over.  (2 weeks and 6 days to go...)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 01:23AM MaryMeg wrote: Hello everybody! It's lovely to hear how people are doing after that charming experience we all started back in January.    I got very anxious a couple of months ago as the anniversaries started ticking by, starting at the end of August when I found my lump.  My surgery was early November, so I'm past all the anniversaries I care about now  and I truly feel like that whole experience was in the past. I feel like I'm pretty much back to normal, and when people ask how I am (using THAT tone of voice.  ("No, REALLY, how are you?")), it's lovely to say, "It's all behind me now, and I'm fine."  And then I knock on wood, cross my fingers, and say a quick prayer to the Saint for Not Tempting Fate. My hair is still very short, but it's very thick again, which is lovely.  I missed it.  My eyebrows and eyelashes seem to have missed the news that it's safe to come back, and they're very sparse and utterly uncommitted to staying, but I'm hoping time will fix that.  And if not, I'm now FABULOUS with an eyebrow brush! Enough adults have asked me if I'm planning to keep my hair this short, ("It REALLY suits you!!") that I am getting a weird suspicion that waistlength scraggly hair wasn't the best look on a 46 year old.  I'll try keeping it short for a while and see how I go.  It doesn't feel like me yet to have short hair.  (Although bald didn't feel much like me either, so I shouldn't complain!) I'm a bit more nervous about my fingernails.  They all turned brown, but didn't fall off, with the Taxol.  Then the brown bits separated and I got white, hollow spaces under each nail, of varying size.  They're pretty much gone, except for my middle fingers, where I still have these large half-moons of white extending way down into the nail which are persistenly NOT growing out.  Much as I've loved having a great excuse to have my nails done every week for the past 5 months, the novelty (and the budget) have worn thin and I'd like to go back to being just me.  My daughter (who is 11) is very conscious of my nails and prefers them covered (even though she was fine with me wandering around bald), but she's just going to have to cope.  I really hope my fingernails get with the programme and start growing properly soon.  If not, they can be a lovely conversation starter.  (And then the conversation will end abruptly and awkwardly. That's always fun.  :-) Has anyone else made Serious Life Changes as a result of the cancer?  I quit my volunteer work (which had been 20-30 hours a week), despite being warned not to make Serious Life Changes during chemo, but it has been fabulous.  I keep thinking that I ought to miss it, but I don't miss it, not one little bit.  I find that weird, since it was pretty much my life for the past 10 years, and am a wee bit nervous that I'll wake up one of these days saying, "What have I DONE?!?!", but so far I'm loving the freedom and the spare time and the ability to slowly but surely tidy up a house, garage, and garden that were attacked by toddlers 13 years ago and have never recovered.    In general, I've found that I'm happy to toss tons of stuff that I've literally kept for decades.  No idea why the stuff mattered to me before and doesn't now, but I'm throwing it out before I change my mind. :-) I'm 3 months into Tamoxifen now, with no real side effects besides strong fatigue.  I suspect my husband thinks I'm grumpy, but it's hard to say if that's the Tamox, since I'm so tired so much of the time.  Still trying to calibrate my activities and interests so I can get to bed at whatever silly time of evening my body wants me to.  So far am not having much luck. 1 down, 19boxes of pills to go. I've been fretting a bit about followups lately.  My surgeon plans for me to have no imaging at all, for surveillance, which I can understand, given that I've had a double Mx, but I managed to get cancer in the first place AFTER the double Mx, so I'm not wild on no imaging.  (Let's be honest, I'd like to start every day with an MRI, just in case.)  Had a wildly unsatisfactory appt with his intern a few weeks ago, (where the poor intern could only repeat what the surgeon had told him to say), and am meeting with the surgeon himself on Monday.  It's frustrating to me that the followups here are with the surgeon, but we are very short of oncologists.  Wish me luck! Ooh look at that, I rambled all over creation again.  She's baaaaaack! Please post, everyone else!   MM, who is going to have a lat reconstruction, but probably not for at least 6 months, which gives me time to decide whether I'd rather live without the lat or without the breast.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 03:46PM MaryMeg wrote: Amy (aimster) I am so impressed that you could do BodyStep at all.  Good for you!  I totally understand about prioritising things (and I am doubly impressed that you are a violin teacher (although I'm trying to blot that out as we've just had 5 weeks of school holidays where I've watched the violin and piano gather dust! I don't know whose pain will be worse when I make the kids start it all up again, theirs or mine. Do you teach regular or Suzuki?) I have read that some exercise, no matter how small, is really important every day.  Even a walk around the block (or around the house) will help with the next day's energy. When things were worst, I tried to calibrate the exercise according to whether it was a day when I could just collapse all day afterwards, or whether I'd be expected to be interacting with humans. :-) (This morning my class had 52 people in it.  Public holidays are fun.  At least as I was pretty well UNDER the stage, the instructor couldn't see me wimping out.  (My excuse was that it was my first class in the wig and I was terrified of losing it.)) I haven't shaved, but am thinking of it.  I got the #4 buzz, which was fabulous while I had hair, but now I'm halfway between "advanced mange" and "Hallowe'en skull".  (Did you know that heads covered in thick hair don't tan?)  I've thought of shaving the stragglers off, but am afraid that when those follicles let go it will just be itchy while the follicle stubs try to climb out. (I'm afraid it will be like the ingrowing from shaving my legs, only worse, since if I scratch this part of my body in public, the way it looks now, grown men will pale and children will scream.) Have worked out that turbans and hats aren't for me.  Funny how personal a choice it is.  I've been wearing a scarf over a turban (since the turban is comfy and it isn't its fault that I feel hideous in it) and it gives some extra volume.  My wig is lovely and I've received lots of compliments on it, but it's a teeny bit small (I have been told in the past that I have a fat head--was that really what they meant?) and I'm afraid that if I move the wrong way, the wig will edge its way towards the middle and ZINGGG! off into space.  May have to work on strategies for that. I'm paranoid that if I wear a hat, I will forget that I have no hair and will take it off, leading to the aforementioned swooning of women and screams of infants. So scarfs it is for now! Webu, I am totally with you on the being expected to be perky thing.  I do not understand how anyone gets into the whole pink thing and puts on the tshirts and signs up for runs and dragon boat races.  Maybe because I'm an introvert?  I love talking to you guys like this, but I do not find anything to be cheerful about this disease about, and turning it into some sort of cheerleaders' pep rally doesn't work for me.  (I'm glad that there are people it works for--I'm just clearly not one of them!)   Melissa, I am SO glad your tumour is shrinking.  May it vanish completely by the end of chemo!  JulieH (and everyone else struggling) PLEASE hang in there.  I remember 22 years ago, my mum (Dx w stage IV ovarian cancer--that's how we found BRCA1, our unwelcome family guest!) saying that she would rather die then and there than go through the rest of her chemo.  But she did, and then did 2 more rounds (including a very early trial of Taxol, which I have always felt very fondly towards, as I feel likeit gave me an extra year of having my mum). It is SO worth it to our families to stick this out.  I keep telling myself that if I mum could do it (and she knew it wasn't going to save her life), then I can.  Of course that's easy to say for me, as I haven't been run over by a bus with it.   MM, planning to fast, starting tomorrow, so I'm "anti-fasting" today.  (Where is the chocolate?!?)

I'm also about to start using tape on the wig, I think.  Has anyone tried one of those gel rings that headcovers.com sells?  I like the idea of them, but they look, with those wires (?) inside, like I'll also be able to receive radio signals on them--are they as uncomfortable as they look?  Or should I just stick with wig tape?  I like the idea of using something like the gel ring with scarves too, as I currently do worry about the scarf slipping, and me going, without noticing, from Grandma Babushka to Night Of The Living Dead at the supermarket.  Might clear the queues at the checkout though!

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 12:02PM MaryMeg wrote: Good morning, everyone!  It's so lovely to hear the updates from you all--I keep checking for updates several times a day.  (Probably a safer addiction than the chocolate one, at least nutrition-wise!)  It sounds like we're all settling into the routine now and the SE are more predictable if not welcome.  Amazing what a big deal hair is.  I do worry about guys who lose their hair--do they go through this?  My DH has more hair on his chin than his head, and I've never wondered if I was hurting his feelings by commenting on it.  If I end up with more hair on my chin than my head, please shoot me! (I realize that isn't a high bar to cross, given what the top of my head looks like at the moment!)  For those with sore heads (physically, not the kind my kids accused me of thsi morning), I've heard that Bonjela (yes, the stuff used for babies who are teething) is really great at soothing the irritation.  (Revised worry--if we start sprouting teeth up there that would be worse than a beard.) Today is my birthday (47!) and once again I declared my descent into decay by carefully dressing in the dark, gathering my keys, and dashing out to a gym class utterly bald.  ("The Elephant Returns" would be the title of the sequel to that, as I attempt to quietly slip upstairs and find the possum in the dark.  I didn't wake anyone on my original evacuation, but they were all up by the time I left the second time.  Why should they sleep if I am having to exercise anyhow?  They should have been up making me cupcakes! Blowing up balloons!  Making origami birthday cakes!) Today I'm off to Look Good, Feel Better and I'm very much looking forward to it.  I've decided that there are lots of things about this Cancer Thing that I really don't mind these days.  Silly things, but real ones.  For instance I could NEVER relax before.  I had 9000 things happening, and my idea of relaxing with a book involved a laptop in one hand, the book in the other, a phone on my armrest, a cup of tea which I'd drink and refill 85 times, a few snacks, better check on the laundry while I'm up, what are the kids up to anyhow, oops, time to start dinner!  Now I lie down and don't move for hours.  I watched 3 consecutive episodes of THE WEST WING in bed last night, perfectly guilt free and then read 3 chapters of THE POWER OF NOW.  Not a washing machine check in sight. I'm also finding that I'm more in touch with my emotional self (as opposed to my hyper-academic, rational self) and it's something that I'm working at consciously (since my hyper-academic self is very aware of the research on suppressing emotions and cancer).  It is so cool to have permission to think about how I'm feeling at a deep level and to deal with that, without apology or excuses.   I know we're supposed to Have Goals During Cancer, as though if we don't aspire to climb Everest we'll Lose The Will To Live, but I'm really happy to have my main goal to be to relax and get to know my inner self better.  Of course, that gets easier as my inner and outer self continue to expand!  (Thanks, Mr Steroids!) (Notice that I blame the steroids, not the 4 pieces of brownie I had for breakfast.  (It was warm!  It didn't turn out well and would be wasted!  It's my birthday! (Note to self: need new excuses for tomorrow!))) What are the positives that the rest of you have found?  It has been amazing to me just how many there are (amidst the not quite as positive things too!)

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 11:49AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi everyone!  I've been reading assiduously, but not posting much at all--keeping up with my kids and using up all my free nap certificates before they expire has been keeping me busy.  (My daily passes expire at 2:30pm, which is when I have to get in the car and drive like a madwoman for 2.5 hours.) Was utterly shocked when on days 20 and 21 after AC#2, I needed naps.  I guess they're not making it up and this stuff is cumulative! BTW, I'm Day 3 after AC#3/4 (3 weekly) +taxol/carboplatin (12xweekly) Serious new problem after AC#3:  I have no neck.  And I'm bald(ish).  I now look like Danny DeVito.  I know the weight gain isn't our focus, but yikes!  I've gained about 6 pounds and am NOT HAPPY! Second serious problem is the worst memory ever.  Chemobrain came crashing down on me a few days ago out of the blue and now I'm forgetting children at events, forgetting half the meal I'm making, etc.  Forgot that I was grilling peppers in the oven the other day and went out for coffee with the griller on full blast.  (We finished the coffee in my house, just grateful it hadn't burned to the ground, accompanied by the gentle scent of carbonized peppers.)   Yesterday was day 2 and I went to the gym at the crack of dawn (since I didn't sleep that night of course) and used a treadmill (which I do on rare occasions,but not often.)  Thanks to Mr Steroids, I was like Wonder Woman.  Just kept going and going and going and going, and thinking that I'd stop soon, but no, I kept going.  Then I didn't crash when I got home either. Felt way better than I had after AC#2--didn't use any metaclopramide at all, which is new.  Had a fabulous day, aside from some fatigue, and kept thanking the Decadron all day.  Till it came to bedtime pill-time and I realized I hadn't taken any.  Oops.  Can you have placebo effect without the placebo? (I did get tons during the chemo, so some must have lasted, but still...) Am now seriously torn.  I feel 100% better than last time, and am convinced that the steroids were causing half my weirdness, yet I don't like to not take things I'm told to take.  Unfortunately it's Saturday, so I'm on my own advice-wise.  Maybe I'll call the ward at the hospital.  Everyone says the steroids are just for energy and anti-nausea, so I can't see the harm in not taking them...(I am such a nightmare patient.)  A funny coincidence is that my 6 mo puppy was fixed yesterday and she's on the same medication schedule as I am with the ondansetron/Zoloft.  No chance of me forgetting hers. (Unless I forget mine of course!) (And it's 9am of day 3 and I have no breakthrough nausea at all, and the last pill I took was at 6pm last night.  Weird.) Oh, and I didn't fast this time.  Just my luck--I'll be the only person alive for whom fasting made the SE worse! Have been reading this group closely and am so glad that so many of us are nearly done with the first round, esp those who have had the really nasty SE.  Add me to those whose hair has kept growing.  I lost NONE in round 2 of the AC, so I still look almost-but not quite bald.  The #4 has grown out to a #9 or something and I look like I'm on the way to a combover (see, just like Danny DeVito!) but I like the fuzzy feel so I'm not shaving it. I hope everyone has a good weekend!   MM, off for a walk in the hills, a grocery expedition, then I'll redeem a few more nap certificates!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 11:22PM MaryMeg wrote: AC, Start 6Jan11, Cycle3/4, Day4. Annie, my chemobrain is doing just like yours.  My kids have a big week at school with multiple trips, swimming etc and I'm terrified that they'll miss the stuff because I'm off in the corner going, "La, la, la!"  Good luck with the blood levels, UTMom.  FIngers crossed that they hold up this time. Sorry to hear about the reflux, AliT.  My husband suffers from that normally and it sounds horrid.  I hope it gets better this time around.   Emily, I'm with you on the misery.  I'm not horribly nauseated, but I still feel really yucky.  I do remember that last cycle, I got up, went to church on Sunday and spent the rest of the day in bed.  This time I went to church on Saturday and just spent the whole day today (Sunday) in bed!  I still can't get my head around this mental state where I'm not really sleeping but have no energy for reading or videos or anything--back to floppy fish mode!   Did I mention that I forgot to take the steroids this time around?  Duh.  Still, have felt much more like a human being and haven't seen any difference in the nausea.  Much less energy, but I couldn't care less about that--I'm not doing anything important anyhow!  (Spent 20 minutes this afternoon on the sofa with a squirt gun waving it at our puppy whenever she slunk towards the cat food.  This is the level of significance of my activities these days!)  I did check with a friend who's an oncology nurse and she said that if I feel okay without the steroids, dump them.  I also dropped over a litre in fluids last night, which has greatly reduced the Danny DeVito look, luckily.I assume that's from the steroids they gave me on Thursday, which were the only ones I had this round. I had no idea they contributed to turning me into a human water balloon. Am dreading the next few days, where the kids have tons on, and am trying to work out what activities we/they can flag if necessary.  Really wish my 7yo didn't have school swimming sports tomorrow, as I feel I can not miss it (I'd feel terrible all year for skipping it), but I was counting on that time for napping!  Two or 3 more days to hang in there....

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 06:54PM MaryMeg wrote: Sue and ScienceGirl, your replies were just what I needed.  I think that at some level, I feel like I'm defined by the stuff I do--first because I'm really a process person, so if I'm not doing things, what is there to me?-- and second because I've got a Master's degree in engineering, but am a SAHM, so I already feel that society considers me a dead loss. :-)  Also, the team I'm on has lost two members this year and I hate that the others are so overworked and feel like physically I can do more than I'm doing.  I've realized that one way that this disease has hit me is that I've lost a lot of my initiative and my interest in planning and undertaking projects, so instead of taking a leadership role on my team, I'm sort of sitting and watching for them to ask me to do something.  I did realize that for me the mental aspect of this would be tricky, but I didn't realize how much! Annie, I think that you and I were making chocolate chip cookies at the same time. :-) I hope you're feeling better. I hope you feel better soon.  I have two sick childen, but as I'm feeling absolutely 100% fine, I'm hoping that that means I've got some WBC!   To be honest, now that I've started REALLY talking to all the acquaintances I know who have had cancer, I have been surprised to find out just how many have ended up in hospital for at least one bout of neutropenia.   For exercise, I'd be really careful.  My memory (based on reading from about 10 years ago, so who knows?) is that heavy exercise suppresses your immune system in the first few hours, and then boosts it after that.  If your immune system is close to shot, you might not want that suppression. :-) I hope you feel better soon.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 04:11PM MaryMeg wrote: webu, mine got itchy a few days beforehand, but I didn't really start to lose any until day 15.  (I'm on A/C).  On day 17 (Saturday) it really started shedding.  That was a lot later than I expected, but once it started, it went quickly.  I've now got about 1/20th (probably less, but it's hard to say) left--enough that with a #4 buzz cut you can see hairs evenly over my head, but all the skin is clearly visible as well--there is probably 1/8" or 1/4" between hairs. By Monday (yesterday here) it was obvious to me that the shedding had stopped--it was really strong for about 36 hours, then tapered off very quickly.  I gather the next treatment will get the rest of it, but I'm going to shave closer to the scalp in the meantime. And I am not letting friends bearing tape into the house. AimeeMac, I haven't had the second round yet (and would also love to hear from those who have), but my understanding is taht the first round sets the pattern, but we get more and more tired as we get further on and so everything just gets a bit worse. Same SE, but more of them. I've just been on the verge of the mouth sores, so I wouldn't be surprised to see them get really annoying later on! Is that what people have experienced?

In any case, I'm a big fan of getting my food through food, not packets and powders and pills.  (So remind me again why I'm about to become a walking, talking bundle of injected, infused, pushed, and ingested chemicals again in 2 days?)

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 11:18AM MaryMeg wrote: jcoutee, what are you doing for head coverings?  I have a fabulous wig, and no one who doesn't know (Wait, that would be everyone in New Zealand!) has guessed--people keep complimenting me on my new hairstyle and telling me how well it suits me.  (Honestly, it suits me better than my long mane ever did.)  The ones who know right away are those who saw me with a buzz cut last week. :-) Good luck with your hair loss.  I got incredibly stressed the day my head started tingling--and then when I got the buzz it was a total non-issue.  (I had expected to cry.)  Then when the buzz fell out, I REALLY expected to cry, but still didn't.  I'm finding that I really don't mind the bald me, although I'd prefer it if I had some colour and looked less like a ghoul from Night Of The Living Dead.  Given that I still have a sparse covering of hair (which has grown considerably since the buzz), I'm glad I didn't get it shaved or I'd be very itchy (and probably ingrown) by now.  I'm sure the rest will be gone in 3 weeks!  SSIrish, I'm not getting the Neulasta.  I think you're right and it's mostly only given if you're on Dose Dense or having WBC issues.   FWIW, I think I'm the resident pathetic one--I actually don't mind the sympathy looks.  Possibly because I'm in a community 10,000 miles from my home (Toronto) and my family.  It's nice to know people care.  The choir member who comes over and hugs me at the sign of peace every Sunday can stop that soon, though. :-)  I'm even okay with the stories of Great Aunt Myrtle, and how much she suffered before This Terrible Disease took her.  I know they're trying to connect with me, and I know my odds (and know that thost numbers are out of date and improving every day) and Great Aunt Myrtle doesn't affect that.  I suspect that if I were Stage IV, I would feel very differently though!  It's interesting the things that we mind and don't mind and how personal it is.  (I am remembering with deep guilt all the people I have told about my Fatal Family Cancer History.  Oops.) Beckie, Sorry to hear that work was so hard.  It does sound like day 5 might be a good day to stay home and sleep next time.  How did wig shopping go? baf4292, I so agree about the nausea.  I remember that from pregnancy--the more tired I am, the more nauseated.  I'm really worried about tomorow (day 2), when my husband will be at work and it is the last day of the summer holidays for my kids.  I'm going to take them to a movie in the morning, and just hope they don't drive me nuts by dinnertime.  (And we're ordering in for dinner!)  My husband is trying to step up to the mark, but I'm trying to hang on as long as possible--by the end of 6 months of chemo that's when he'll need to be using up his leave to help me! Julie, I had no idea that the Pacific NW knew Nanaimo Bars (although it makes since since Nanaimo is on Vancouver Island).  They are really common throughout most of Canada--most cafes will have them (along with butter tarts and doughnuts of course--did you know that per capita Canadians eat ten times as many doughnuts as Americans?  My kids thought they'd died and gone to heaven when we visited Toronto and they saw 3 doughnut shops on every corner!) AimeeMac, I LOVE what your friend said about us being replaceable at work but not to our families.  That is so utterly true, but it had never occurred to me before.  Duh. (Possibly because my children speak so hopefully of their desire to replace me with a less unreasonable mother?) And now I'd better get moving, so I can farm out the children and go get my next dose of drugs.  (Do we get to be honorary rock stars after all the drugs we take?)   MM, wondering if I drink some blue food dye (I loved the cupcake story) if I can make my, er, output purple today?

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 10:34AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi Betsy, That;s a hard position to be in, about the testing. I had a BMX (supposedly prophylactically, but BRCA1 had other ideas) 4 years ago, with a free TRAM reconstruction.  I was very very happy with it.  I loved waking up from the surgery not flat, I loved having my own tissue, with natural jiggling, not having to do fills or worry about replacing foreign objects, and I was just more comfortable with being all me.  I also loved the feel and shape of my new breasts.  And the tummy tuck was awesome! The surgery was long (about 8 hours) and the recovery was huge.  Two weeks of being hunched over (via the tummy tuck), 4 weeks of having no stamina and no real ability to do much, another month or two of being very tired (and I stayed off my work in a preschool for the whole10 week term).  It was about 6 months before I was totally back to myself, but I was back to being able to do anything (just not much at a time) after about 4-6 weeks. Full arm mobility took a long time--probably over a year.  Still can't sit up without using my hands or rocking. I figure that just lets me off doing situps! My husband helpfully had surgery on his knee when I was three weeks post surgery, so for 2 days I had to do everything at home and I ended up with an antibiotic-resistant infection for which I still sport the scar. (But it's on moon crater side, so we don't see it now. :-) For me it was absolutely the right choice.  Good luck looking at your options.  PM me if you want to talk more about it (or if anyone else does).
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 01:51PM MaryMeg wrote: The cut across the tummy is big but straightforward--they're just taking things out and closing you up. The chest scars are minimal.  I have a cut along the underwire line, and then a line from the midpoint there to the bottom of the nipple, that's all.  I had skin sparing but not nipple-sparing (since nipples are made of breast tissue).  There is a lot of work inside though, connecting things up, and you really want a good plastic surgeon, to make sure the flap survives in its new spot.  New Orleans is the best place in the country for this type of surgery (or was 5 years ago), but I'm sure there are other local centres of excellence.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 03:44PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi Reddawn, So sorry that you have to join our special club here! A cycle is a single dose.  I also find that terminology really weird and confusing. It looks from what you have said that you will have AC once every 3 weeks--four times all together--, and then Taxol will be weekly for 12 weeks.  That's normal for AC+T. You are very welcome to hang out with us, but you might not find it that useful as we are mostly finishing up chemo.  There is a group at http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/769067 which is for those starting chemo this month.  It can be really helpful to hang out with those on roughly the same schedule, to cheer each other on. (On the other hand, we're great at answering questions, since between us all we've seen a lot now, so ask away if you like!) I hope the port placement goes well and that chemo goes smoothly for you.  It's a grind, but we're lucky to have these options! We'll be cheering for you!   MaryMeg, who did ACx4 and Taxol and has two Taxol left...

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 06:32PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi Julie! I felt my cancer.  It was a lump right in the middle, by my sternum (which is why I'm so keen to get the nodes there irradiated--they can't examine them surgically because the ribcage is in the way).  You'd hardly have thought breast tissue went that far into the middle (which is probably why it was left behind in the mastectomies). My tumour scar is less than an inch from my sternum. (So much for scoop-necked or v-necked tops for me!)  My oncologist says (and what I've read agrees) that MRI is the most reliable way to do surveillance after mx.  I had a CT after the cancer was diagnosed and it didn't pick up my tumour, even though the referral identified it! And mammograms work best on breast tissue because of the density (or lack) of the tissue.  The trick is the frequency and convincing those that pay for them that it's worth it. When surgeons do a mastectomy, they work very very hard to scrape off every last breast tissue cell they can possibly get, so many do feel that there is little point in surveillance, as you have to spend huge sums of money to detect even one cancer (since the cancers are relatively rare).  I dont' know how that works for those of us who have proven that we get breast cancer already. :-) My neutrophils went down to 1, or 1.1 after each chemo too.  I'd never heard of losing brows and lashes AFTER taxol.  Hardly seems fair.  I might go and tape mine on right now!   MM, also about to start insisting on getting CA125 tests done again since my risk of ovarian cancer is the same as my (theoretical) risk of breast cancer was, and I'm a lot more nervous about ovarian CA!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 10:50PM MaryMeg wrote: Annie,  I'm starting with AC and I had a MUGA scan last week or the week before (Christmas Eve, I think it was!).  My husband is a doctor and he was a bit freaked out that my ejection fraction is already way too low, but that's life.  I guess I'll just have to make sure to keep my heart in good condition then! Aimster,  BodyPump and other exercise has been a lifeline for me through this.  I really notice it on the days that I don't get decent exercise--except that normally "decent" exercise has been a short run or 25 minutes of weights.  I tend to do a small number of heavy reps, and I WAAAAY overestimated how much I'd be able to handle in BodyPump!  I do plan to go back, but I don't know when or whether I'll have any weight on the bar!  In the meantime, back to BodyBalance (do you guys call it BodyFlow?) and running and free weights. :-)  I was very proactive on the wig front.  I knew that my hair would come out eventually, and because I have been waiting for a long while for my onco appt and was afraid that the summer/Christmas holidays would affect it, I got in early.  (Here 2/3 of people take their vacation in January, and Wellington isn't very big and there's only one real place to get a wig--and as it turns out, the lady who does it was going to be away for most of Jan, so i'm glad I got it when I did.  I've got waist length, very thick hair, and getting a wig that would suit me mattered a lot to me, partly because I've tried short hair before and never had any luck (just looked like an electrified bush, due to the hair thickness), and partly because my Mum (also BRCA1, died of OVCA 17 years ago) looked like she was wearing a dead muskrat and I was keen to avoid that option.   Had a helpful friend (very very VERY analytic type, bordering on aspie) tell me that hair loss "doesn't matter" because the effect is "only psychological".  She was trying to be helpful, so I didn't get into it with her, but I know that for me, the hair loss is going to be a big deal.  I really like my hair!  Aimster, my oopherectomy was really no big deal.  I had a month or two of waking up sweating and that was absolutely it.  Iwas really really lucky.  I did a low dose of HRT for about 9 months (after consulting right left and centre about it and finally deciding that the impact of menopause on my bones would be the key factor) and am now wondering if that is why the cancer is ER+, which is not common for BRCA1 types.  (Of couse the side question is whether it would have emerged at all without it, but if that level and duration of HRT gave me cancer in the teeny number of breast cells I had left, then I was doomed anyhow!)    Am definitely getting nervous.  My chemo starts on Thursday (AC) and on Sunday, my two younger children (7 and 10) are going away to camp for the first time (a 45 minute drive away through the mountains) AND I've been offered the chance to sing a solo at church on Sunday morning.  What were the odds, eh? Do any of you wise women know if I'll likely be up to singing at church?  I suspect not, but the chance comes so rarely, I'd hate to give it up for anything!    Mary Margaret, greedy. :-)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 06:46PM MaryMeg wrote: JulieH, you are a marvel, keeping track of us this way!  Thank you so much! You are really helping to pull us into a community. I had my chemo on Thursday (which makes me day 5 here in New Zealand) and it went really really well.  I did do my solo at church yesterday and was very grateful to get the chance.  I've been feeling bulletproof and full of energy (except for needing the odd nap) until today.  Now all my drugs are gone (To panic or not to panic, That is the question?) and I just had a 3 hour nap to combat a tiny bit of nausea from this morning.  Oh, and a wee bit of fatigue. :-) The steroids have been making me hungry and affecting night-time sleep, so I had planned on a massive nap today.  I went to a 6am BodyPump class this morning (so I could be home before my husband went to work), then made a cooked breakfast, took the dog for a walk, finished painting the guest room, and did the annual change of our 300 litres of stored earthquake water (living in shaky NZ, you know!), before taking my 12 yo son on 90 minutes of errands today.  Just made it home before I crashed--talk about tired!  Luckly my 7 and 10 year old are at camp for the week--how perfect is that timing? Am feeling incredibly lucky, so far.   MM, who does not plan to stir from this chair for the rest of the day!

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 10:37PM MaryMeg wrote: No Ativan here, Melissa.  I did get a Zopiclone prescription, but it leaves a hideous aftertaste for me for days, so I'd have to be desperate to do it again.  I'd rather drift and read all night and then nap in the daytime if I need to (on the days when I can!) Emily I am with you on the water thing--can't believe how weird water can taste!  I did find that the colder any drink was, the less weird it tasted.  I had a lot of cup of soup--the salt made it palatable, while sweet didn't work for me.  Interesting how different we are.  (And normally I'm addicted to green tea, but I haven't managed 3 cups since the AC started.  Yech!)   MM, whose kids do love that I'm suddenly buying lots of fruit juices (for the weeks when the chemo is wearing off).

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 12:22AM MaryMeg wrote: Hi everyone! Tammy, my kids are keen for my hair to go too. (They're 7, 10 and 12).  Oddly, it was coming out with very little resistance 3 days ago but is now hanging on again.  Silly stuff. (I'm day9 now.) Proud_Mom, I'm with you about the hair only in my case it's washing it.  It's very long and thick and I only wash it every 6 days or so because it's such a production and I refuse to do it 2 days before it comes out.  Of course not knowing when it will go is making that difficult!  WRT the mouth sores, I had a few days earlier this week where I woke feeling them coming on, but that seems to have passed.  I hate being confused!  I'm also sleeping oddly, but I'm napping whenever the urge hits, so that is bound to be part of it. I'm taking a "targetted activities" approach--working out what I HAVE to do in a given day (like picking my kids up from camp today, and going to a 6am gym class) and then I fit everything else around it.  Some days that has meant multiple short naps, some days it has meant one long nap, and some days I've just not managed anything else except the things I really needed to do. It's very unpredictable, so focussing on the essentials and dropping the rest has been helpful. Annie, I hope you're starting to feel better! Melissa, if the bone aches are from Neulasta, some find Claritin helpful.  I hope you find something good for you. slcst, I love that bracelet idea.  I have been wandering around saying, "1 down, 7 to go" and feel very pleased (until I remember what the last 3 reps feel like in a gym class :-)  JulieH, I am really struggling with how much to slow down.  I have to say, I don't see this as a speed bump, as some advise people like me with early stage BC to regard it.  Because I'm BRCA1 and because both my mum and my aunt died at around my age, I feel like I need to give it ALL my attention and do every trivial thing I can to increase my chances.  (I have a baby brother and 2 cousins who went totally off the rails (as in ruined adulthoods now, 20 years later--one now moving into a second generation of it) from losing their mums as teenagers.  (I was 29, but my brother was only 17), so I am obsessed with doing everything I can.) So I'm feeling like rest and exercise and diet, really the only things available for me to do right now, need to be my full focus, and I'm reluctant to take on any commitments that I'll have difficulty dropping if I need to.  I feel like a complete slacker, though, which isn't helping. I'm a SAHM with a big volunteer job (national VP of an early childhood service with 500 centres) and I hate letting people down, but I find I just can't care about doing the work at the moment. I feel like my important job is recovery, and it's irresponsible of me to take on other things that will make that harder (i.e. to fulfill my spontaneous desires for naps :-)  Then I look at all of you out there, working through chemo, and feel like a dilettante.  (Or would if I could spell it.)  I'm normally the sort of person who is up to my eyeballs in everything (I'm also on 5 committees at church, sing in the choir, am a trustee for our school's board, and run adult education workshops), so figuring out what I should be doing and how much I should be doing, and not losing my self-esteem (or dying of boredom, once my initial drive to research everything in sight is fulfilled) in the process is a huge issue for me. But at the same time I will hate it if I struggle to keep up with things that aren't always fun in the first place (Ooh, can I write up minutes of my subcommittee meeting, please?) and then get a recurrence.  The world will not end if I am not in the centre of it.  Or will it? Sorry for going on so long, but I'd love to hear how the rest of you are managing this and how you are feeling about it (bearing in mind that we are all coming from very different places).   MM, who would possibly feel less like a woman on a mission had I not already had the preventative double mx 4 years ago and then still managed to get cancer.  (If IT is on a mission, then *I* can be on a mission!) I'd love to know how the rest of you are handling it. (And I have to say, I'm not obsessing over dying etc etc.  I

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 06:21PM MaryMeg wrote: Jcoutee,  As Julie said, I had a prophylactic BMX a few years ago and still managed to get cancer.  At the moment, they're saying that it reduces 95% of the risk of BC (for those who never had it), so I just hapened to be the 1 in 20 to get unlucky.  A BMX removes as many cells as they can get but there will always be a small number left.  I'm BRCA1 though, so my DNA repair mechanisms are wonky, so any single cell going haywire was likely to be bad news.  if your original risk was normal, then a BMX would offer you more protection than it did me.  I agree with what the others have said--it's so important to go with your gut. On the BRCA websites there is a lot of discussion about options, but the research is solid--that the results that work best for people are the ones that feel right for THEM--and it's different for everyone.  No matter what the choice is, if it doesn't feel right, it is likely to not work well.  Good luck with the choices!    MM< waaaay behind so many of you, with 10 Taxol/carbo left, then rads (then AIs for years...)

Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 02:02PM MaryMeg wrote: Thanks for asking, ProudMom_Wife! I'm doing okay, better in the last week or so. Yes, I've found the combination of carboplatin and taxol quite a rough one.  I only get carbo every 3 weeks, luckily, but the last one was a weekend when my DH went over to Australia for his sister's 50th, so he was gone the whole weekend, and the one before was Easter weekend (and being Catholic, (and I'm a soloist in the choir), it's a biiiiig weekend for us. So I've spent lots of time strugglign to get through those and then collapsing once it was allowed again. I do feel a wee bit like a 1940s MGM child star--caffeine to get me moving, drugs to help me sleep.  Drugs for my tummy, drugs for the itching!  The NZ pharmaceutical industry (and Coca Cola Amatil) will collapse when I'm done chemo! I've had some excitement.  I got to use my litte "Neutropenic Fever Alert!" card when I got a fever of 38.7 (101.6) a couple of weeks ago.  My favourite part was when the triage nurse took my temperature, looked at my file online, then stepped to a microphone and bellowed "CODE TWO IN ROOM 4! CODE TWO IN ROOM 4!" I felt very special.  Sadly, that was the extent of the drama.  No source of infection was found, and they sent me home (at 11pm, without a car) after they'd done the IV antibiotics.  (My least favourite part was where I spent 75 minutes feeling utterly miserable in the waiting room AFTER presenting my little card.  However, I'm told that Reception Is To Be Re-educated on what those cards mean.) I got a less exciting fever last week (100.5) and ignored it (since DH was going to his sister's birthday the next morning and I was afraid he'd stay home if I was being all Chemo Drama Queen.)  Unfortunately I mentioned it to a nurse at chemo the next week and YIKES did I get my head ripped off.  I won't ignore any such thing again, I promise.  (She had a patient with a similar fever die on her once.  She had been waiting 2 hours till her husband came home from work so he could watch the kids.) I had an interesting experience about 10 days ago.  When I went in for chemo (this was the day I got the mild fever and didn't tell) my immune stuff was low, so I got the Neupogen shots (called G-CSF here--why use a word, if you can use a random string of letters?).  Has anyone else found that the shots affected their energy levels?  By the day of the last shot, I had tons and tons more energy than beforehand. I was making proper dinners, doing laundry--all sorts of things that previously I'd just thought about, then gone for a nap.  Nothing else changed in that time--no transfusion, no hearty eating of liver (yuck!), and I know that going into the shots my hemoglobin was very low --but it was at the end too.  THe only change was neutrophils and WBC, which both shot way up. (Neutrophils have been in the 0.5 - 2.0 range for 4 months, but were 5.5 last week.) I'm back to low energy again, but I was very grateful for my week of feeling like Superwoman. (I think my husband was too.  The kids less so, since takeaway and hot dogs featured less prominently.)  (Funny how you don't trust yourself though--today I look at the work I should do and jsut want a nap, but despite how much I did in the last week, the voice in my head isn't saying "You're not very well", it's saying "You're being lazy!" I'm a bit sad this week.  Last weekend was my preschool's annual conference and I stepped down from my role as national VP.  It was definitely the right decision (mostly because I am SO over going away every 3rd or 4th weekend--not that I have been lately), but I'm now in that crisis of identity that comes from no longer being able to say, "Yes, I'm at home, but I'm in full time volunteer work.  Well, <cough, cough>, I'm national vice president of the New Zealand Playcentre Federation.  Why yes, we do have 500 licensed centres!" Now I get to say, "I'm a housewife!" (And judging from the state of the house, not a very successful one!) It was a wonderful conference, and I got the kind of magnificent send-off that you only get when secretly people are worried that you're quitting because you're dying (I wanted to wear a placard that said "Stage IIa", but that wouldn't have meant much).  And I was lucky that my energy lasted throughout it.  And I'll still be in touch via facebook, but I'm a bit lost this week, just the same! So there you go, I'm still here, just lurking (and being jealous of all you that are done chemo.)  I finish on June 16th, and will be very glad of it!   MM, whose wig has gone into rehab, since it was turning into a very mangy Possum.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 03:04PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi ProudMom!  I've still got 2 left and am definitely counting the days. Had my last carbo/taxol on Thursday and had an awful weekend--to the point where DH took the day off today, assuming I woulnd't be able to even get the kids off to school without help.  (He's just mopped the kitchen floor, so I'm glad to have him home. :-)  Not a ton of nausea, but just icky feeling, and an astonishing level of fatigue. For the most part, things should get better from here on for me though, since I only have 2 Taxol left.  I probably have a blood transfusion in my immediate future, (which I'm dreading, but I am definitely looking forward to the boost in energy--I went to bed for the night at 3pm yesterday!) and then I have a few weeks off before rads. I just got a phone call from my dentist's receptionist, saying, "We were just wondering if you were coming in for your hygenist appointment this morning?"  to which the answer was, "Actually, no." (I didn't receive the booking notice, but normally I'd leap in the car and head straight over, full of apologies.  Not today however!  Oops.  This is called "Playing the Cancer card", my children!)   MM, who did buy groceries (since DH, while expert at feeding the family all weekend, wasn't so expert at finding the grocery store on the weekend), but I had to sit down 4 times while putting them away.  I am a precious, fragile little princess, I am. :-) P.S.  So very glad to hear of all the positive news and those finishing chemo.  Very glad that your mammogram was normal, AimeeMac! P.P.S.  I have the world's shortest eyelashes and am so proud of them!

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 07:15PM MaryMeg wrote: Hi Kimala, and hi Julie!  I'm sorry to hear that you're having such a rough time, Kimala.  Have you got any further details on how they plan to treat the cancer?  I know quite a few people for whom it seems to be more of a chronic illness than something that they can just whack on the head and kill.  I hope yours is easily controllable. Julie, that's no good at all that your husband's cancer has come back!  (You guys are sure keeping up the workload on your oncologist, aren't you?)  I'll say a prayer that the excision does the trick. Nothing exciting here.  I'm well and fit and happy (and doing insane amounts of travel, due to winning a prize of zillions of free flights.  Ten years ago I'd have been prudent and sensible and blown it all on one big trip (we have to still pay for accommodation etc--just the flights are free) but instead, having a much clearer "shall not pass this way again" voice in my head, we are having lots of teeny yet long-haul trips (3 days in Beijing anyone?)  We will still be eating cat food in our retirement, but not to the same degree as if we hadn't won the flights, so it's all good. I am struggling terribly with chemo brain still.  Anyone else?  I went back to university this (calendar) year, and nearly lost my mind trying to study in June.  Aside from playing whack-a-mole with people who cluelessly try to tell me that it's just middle age (and HOW would they know unless they can get into my brain?) I haven't found any helpful approach to it yet.  Have done some reading and Ritalin looks worth a try, but my surgeon (who is my point of call for after-care) and my GP clearly think that the cancer has addled my brain in other ways.  (C'mon guys, if I wanted serious drugs, Ritalin is not where I would start!  As well, I have a bedroom drawer with enough sleeping pills to make me Rip van Winkle.  (Hmm, maybe I should find a more secure place for them.)) Chemo brain increases with chemo dosage (and I got AC+Taxol+ carboplatin as well) AND Tamoxifen (tick there too!) so it looks like this is long term/permanent and I really would like to find some relief! Would love to hear if any of the rest of you have experienced this (before I go and hang out on a forum actually intended for that conversation). I hope you're all doing well, MaryMeg.
